His best friends tell him about girls in the city that get high and easy to make out with when they smoke cigarettes. He questions their story but still decides to join them to the city and find out for himself.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Zbigniew Preisner on THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE
Description: Zbigniew Preisner, Poland’s leading film composer, enjoyed a long collaboration with director Krzysztof Kieślowski, scoring every one of his films beginning with 1985’s NO END. In 1998, he released “Requiem for My Friend,” an album dedicated to the director. This exclusive interview was conducted at the composer’s home in Kraków in July 2006.

A pioneer in the field of electronic music, Eduard Artemyev composed scores for three of Andrei Tarkovsky’s films (SOLARIS and THE MIRROR, in addition to STALKER). In this 2000 interview, Artemyev recalls the process of composing for STALKER.

CARNIVAL OF SOULS director Herk Harvey and screenwriter John Clifford were employed for over thirty years by the Lawrence, Kansas–based industrial film giant the Centron Corporation. Between them, Harvey and Clifford made over four hundred films for Centron, from which the following segment has been selected.
This interview with DHEEPAN director Jacques Audiard was conducted in Paris in February 2017.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Ettore Scola on A SPECIAL DAY
Description: In this interview with director Ettore Scola, conducted in Rome in May 2015, he discusses the arc of his career and why he wanted to create the character of Gabriele in A SPECIAL DAY.
In the following program, produced in 2015, Charlie Chaplin biographer David Robinson explores the evolution and personal nature of LIMELIGHT.
The following interview with Noah Isenberg, author of the British Film Institute’s monograph on DETOUR and “Edgar G. Ulmer: A Filmmaker in the Margins,” was recorded in New York in November 2018.

This 2003 video interview with Kaneto Shindo shows the acclaimed writer/director discussing the genesis and filming of ONIBABA, as well as reflecting on his diverse and prolific career within the Japanese film industry.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Ludovic Cortade on THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN
Description: In this 2010 interview, French film scholar Ludovic Cortade, author of “Le cinéma de l’immobilité,” discusses the themes and style of THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN.
The following interview with actor Geraldine Chaplin was recorded in 2007.
In this audio excerpt from an interview conducted in 1972, Alfred Hitchcock talks to filmmaker Peter Bogdanovich about his early years as a director.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Oliver Reed on “The Merv Griffin Show”
Description: This episode of “The Merv Griffin Show” from April 25, 1980, features actor Oliver Reed, along with filmmaker Orson Welles and entertainer Charo. Reed shares various anecdotes as well as his thoughts on film acting.
In the following interview, recorded in 2010, writer-director Masahiro Shinoda discusses the production of PALE FLOWER.
This interview with actor Liv Ullmann was produced in 2018.
This 2014 documentary features interviews with PHOENIX director Christian Petzold; actors Nina Hoss, Nina Kunzendorf, and Ronald Zehrfeld; and production designer K. D. Gruber.
This interview, in which director Robert Altman discusses THE PLAYER and the Hollywood film industry, was recorded in New York in December 1992.

CARNIVAL OF SOULS director Herk Harvey and screenwriter John Clifford were employed for over thirty years by the Lawrence, Kansas–based industrial film giant the Centron Corporation. Between them, Harvey and Clifford made over four hundred films for Centron, from which the following segment has been selected.
The star of SUPERBAD and JUNO on a lifetime of moviegoing
Conducted in 2004, this interview with Volker Schlöndorff features the writer-director discussing the making of YOUNG TÖRLESS and reflecting on its impact.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Erik Skjoldbjærg and Stellan Skarsgård on INSOMNIA
Description: In this twenty-minute conversation, recorded in Oslo in January 2014, director Erik Skjoldbjærg and actor Stellan Skarsgård discuss the making of INSOMNIA, including the development of the script, the creation of the lead character of Engstrom, and their interest in inverting the genre norms of film noir.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Making of AND EVERYTHING IS GOING FINE
Description: In this interview piece, produced in March 2012, director Steven Soderbergh, producer Kathleen Russo, and editor Susan Littenberg talk about the evolution of AND EVERYTHING IS GOING FINE.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Shohei Imamura on THE INSECT WOMAN
Description: This twenty-one minute interview with Shohei Imamura was conducted by film critic Tadao Sato.

In this visual essay, Charlie Chaplin biographer Jeffrey Vance draws from film stills and historical imagery to discuss the making of THE GREAT DICTATOR, the anticipation surrounding Chaplin’s first all-talkie production, and the enduring influence of his bold satire.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Adriano Aprà on Marco Ferreri and DILLINGER IS DEAD
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2009, Italian film historian Adriano Aprà discusses the career of Marco Ferreri and the singularity of DILLINGER IS DEAD.

Director Nicolas Roeg’s son Luc played the young boy in WALKABOUT (he is credited as Lucien John). Luc Roeg is now a London-based film producer whose credits include LET HIM HAVE IT, SPIDER, and Nicolas Roeg’s TWO DEATHS. In this video interview, recorded in 2010 in London, he discusses the shooting of WALKABOUT and his father’s work.

This interview with JULES AND JIM cowriter Jean Gruault was conducted in April 1986 at the Cinémathèque française in Paris for Rainer Gansera’s documentary WORKING WITH TRUFFAUT. Only a few minutes of it were used in that film, but the Criterion Collection was granted access to the footage and assembled this twenty-one-minute version.

Directed by Anahita Ghazvinizadeh • 2013 • United States /  /  /  / Lilly plans to get her ears pierced, until her parents’ incessant quarreling begins to cause problems. This skillful look at shifting family dynamics insightfully explores the stages children go through when processing change. Anahita Ghazvinizadeh’s subtle approach leads to a powerful payoff. The short film was the winner of the Cinéfondation award at the 2013 Cannes Film Festival.
The following 2011 video essay was written and narrated by film studies professor Annette Insdorf, author of “Double Lives, Second Chances: The Cinema of Krzysztof Kieślowski.”

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Louis Malle on THE FIRE WITHIN
Description: In September 1994 Louis Malle was interviewed for German television, by journalist Angelika Wittlich, about his career in cinema. The interview, which took place in his office in Paris, would be one of his last—he passed away on November 23, 1995. Presented here is an excerpt concerning THE FIRE WITHIN.
Directed by Josh Safdie and Benny Safdie • 2012 • United States /  / The black balloon, an alien in a crowded land, searches for some semblance of companionship after losing all of its friends.
Directed by Andrei Cretulescu • 2015 • Romania /  / One girl. One car. One night. No coincidence.

The following is a 2006 interview with Harry Alan Towers. Born in 1920, in London, Towers started as an actor and radio writer, before establishing a production company, Towers of London, in 1946. In the early 1950s, he produced two radio series starring and written by Orson Welles: “The Lives of Harry Lime” and “The Black Museum.”
In this interview, conducted in 2014, film music scholar Jeff Smith, author of “The Sounds of Commerce,” analyzes William Alwyn’s unusual score for ODD MAN OUT.
This 2002 film by Jacques Tati scholar Stéphane Goudet traces Tati's life and work through clips from his films and rare photos and archival material.
This 2002 film by Jacques Tati scholar Stéphane Goudet traces Tati's life and work through clips from his films and rare photos and archival material.
In this short 2013 documentary, film writer John Bengtson and visual-effects expert Craig Barron discuss Harold Lloyd’s innovative use of stunts, locations, and effects in his “thrill pictures.”

For his film FOR ALL MANKIND, director Al Reinert chose to record audio-only interviews with the Apollo astronauts. Here, Reinert presents a compilation of on-camera interviews with fifteen astronauts, excerpted from a few of his favorite films about the Apollo missions and from two events for the fortieth anniversaries of Apollo 7 and Apollo 8.

This short 2005 documentary about EUROPA’s production features interviews with film historian Peter Schepelern, actor Jean-Marc Barr, producer Peter Aalbaek Jensen, assistant director Tomas Gislason, cowriter Niels Vorsel, and prop master Peter Grant.

In these interviews, conducted in Stockholm in August 2005, actors Gunnel Lindblom and Birgitta Pettersson reflect on working with director Ingmar Bergman and their experiences making THE VIRGIN SPRING.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): On the Comprehensive Version of MR. ARKADIN
Description: In the following documentary, produced in 2006, film historians and archivists Stefan Drössler and Claude Bertemes discuss the principles behind the creation of a new, unique version of MR. ARKADIN. Director and Orson Welles confidant Peter Bogdanovich shares his understanding of Welles’s intentions and style to address the differences in the edit.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Ichikawa and Curtis on FIRES ON THE PLAIN
Description: The following interviews with director Kon Ichikawa and actor Mickey Curtis were recorded in 2005 and 2006. The two reminisce about their experiences making FIRES ON THE PLAIN.
Directed by Les Blank • 1980 • United States /  / As a result of a lost bet with his assistant, Errol Morris, director Werner Herzog must eat his own shoe.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Christopher Hobbs on THE LONG DAY CLOSES
Description: In this interview, production designer Christopher Hobbs describes building sets for THE LONG DAY CLOSES, creating the special effects, and the unique process of reconstructing director Terence Davies’s childhood memories. The interview was conducted at Hobbs’s home in France in September 2013.
Filmmaker Claire Denis served as first assistant director on PARIS, TEXAS. She appears here in conversation with critic Kent Jones in October 2009.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Robert Altman and Garry Trudeau on TANNER ’88
Description: In this video discussion recorded in June 2004, director Robert Altman and writer Garry Trudeau reminisce about their shared political interests and successful collaboration on the groundbreaking series TANNER ’88.

Presented here is a 2009 interview with Michael Fitzgerald, whose production credits include THE PLEDGE, COLOR ME KUBRICK, and THE THREE BURIALS OF MELQUIADES ESTRADA. WISE BLOOD was his first film, and he worked with John Huston again on 1984’s UNDER THE VOLCANO.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): God Respects Us When We Work, but Loves Us When We Dance
Description: Directed by Les Blank • 1968 • United States /  / Hippies and flower children dance and create rituals at the historic Los Angeles "Love-In" of Easter Sunday, 1967.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Shooting the OPEC Sequence of CARLOS
Description: This documentary shows how director Olivier Assayas and his crew re-created the historic events of December 21, 1975, when Carlos the Jackal and his team raided OPEC headquarters in Vienna during a meeting of the group’s ministers. It was shot on the set of CARLOS and directed by Arnaud Giocomini, for Film en Stock.

The following interview with director Seijun Suzuki was recorded during a retrospective of his work by the Japan Foundation and Los Angeles Filmforum at the Nuart Theatre in Los Angeles in March 1997.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Scénario de SAUVE QUI PEUT (LA VIE)
Description: In 1979, director Jean-Luc Godard submitted the following 20-minute video to the Centre national du cinéma, in place of a screenplay, to secure financing for his new film, EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF.
This interview with director Chantal Akerman was conducted in Paris in April 2009.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): René Clair on I MARRIED A WITCH
Description: In this audio interview from the late fifties, director René Clair discusses the differences between working in commercial and experimental cinema, as well as the overall state of the art of film. The interview was conducted in New York by film historian Gideon Bachmann, for his radio program “The Film Art.”

Directed by Ousmane Sembène • 1963 • Senegal /  /  /  / This groundbreaking short film, which won first prize at the 1963 Touris Film Festival in France, was the directorial debut of Ousmane Sembène. /  /  /  / Restored in 2013 by the Cineteca di Bologna/L’Immagine Ritrovata laboratory and Éclair, in association with The Film Foundation’s World Cinema Project; INA, Institut National de l’Audiovisuel; and the Sembène Estate.  Restoration funded by Doha Film Institute.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): PERSONA’s Prologue: A Poem in Images
Description: The following visual essay by Ingmar Bergman scholar Peter Cowie, produced in 2013, focuses on the first seven minutes of PERSONA.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Angelo Badalamenti on TWIN PEAKS: FIRE WALK WITH ME
Description: The following is a 2017 interview with composer Angelo Badalamenti.

The first assistant director on UGETSU, Tokuzo Tanaka would later go on to direct several episodes of the famous ZATOICHI film series, starring Shintaro Katsu. He was interviewed in Tokyo, in May 2005, about his work with director Kenji Mizoguchi.

In 1978, filmmaker Hollis Frampton was interviewed by filmmaker Adele Friedman for the Video Data Bank at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago. Presented here are excerpts from that conversation.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Double Obsession: Seki, Sada, and Oshima
Description: Nagisa Oshima’s EMPIRE OF PASSION is often paired with this preceding film, the sexually explicit IN THE REALM OF THE SENSES (1976). In this 2009 video essay, Catherine Russell, author and professor of film studies at Concordia University in Montreal, looks at the two films side by side.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Timothy Corrigan on THE TIN DRUM
Description: In this 2012 interview, film scholar Timothy Corrigan (“New German Cinema: The Displaced Image”) discusses the themes and style of THE TIN DRUM and its place in the history of German cinema.

In this interview, conducted in 2004 by film critic Jean A. Gili, director Dino Risi discusses the true stories that inspired IL SORPASSO, why Vittorio Gassman was an unexpected choice for the leading role, and the film’s lasting influence on Italian cinema.
This second segment in a three-part program from 2005, produced by Les Films de Mon Oncle, focuses on the costumes of MON ONCLE.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Sheila Sim on A CANTERBURY TALE
Description: The following video interview with actress Sheila Sim (Lady Attenborough) was taped in London in February 2006.

The following interview with actor Jenny Agutter was conducted in 2008 for Potemkine Productions in France. In it, she discusses how she came to be cast in WALKABOUT and what it was like to work with director Nicolas Roeg and actor David Gulpilil.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): A Bucket of Water and a Glass Matte
Description: In this 2010 program, Craig Barron and Ben Burtt, leading experts in the fields of visual and sound effects, respectively, discuss the techniques used and choices made by Charlie Chaplin and his crew on MODERN TIMES.
In this 2001 interview, Georgian-French filmmaker Otar Iosseliani (CHASING BUTTERFLIES; FAREWELL, HOME SWEET HOME) talks about the influence that Jean Vigo has had on his own work.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): The Wurlitzer: Nathan Barr and Mark Herman
Description: Presented here are two rarely seen Harold Lloyd shorts: Over the Fence (1917), the first "Glasses Character" film, and That's Him (1918). Lloyd lost many of his early films in a fire, and these have been restored from the best existing elements-a 9.5 mm print and a 28 mm print, respectively-and are accompanied by new scores performmed by Mark Herman on a historic Wurlitzer theater pipe organ owned by film and television composer Nathan Barr. Also included are a discussion about these early film formats by Dino Everett, archivist at the University of Souther California's Hugh M. Hefner Moving Image Archive, and a video tour of the Wurlitzer organ lead by Barr and Herman.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Harriet Andersson on CRIES AND WHISPERS
Description: In this conversation, recorded in Stockholm in January 2012, film historian Peter Cowie and actor Harriet Andersson talk about her work in CRIES AND WHISPERS.

In this 1981 German television program, “Godards Kameramänner,” directed by Michael Klier and part of the series “Kino 81,” cinematographers Renato Berta and William Lubtchansky discuss their collaborative effort on EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF.
The athlete and author on a lifetime of moviegoing

In the following conversation, filmed in Los Angeles in August 2017, director Donna Deitch, cinematographer Robert Elswit, and production designed Jeannine Oppewall discuss their collaboration in creating the look of DESERT HEARTS.

Max Ophuls adapted three short stories by Guy de Maupassant for his film LE PLAISIR. In this piece, created in 2008, film scholar Jean-Pierre Berthomé discusses Ophuls’s original script, in which a different short story, “Paul’s Mistress,” makes up the third episode in place of “The Model.” Berthomé examines how and why various changes were made to thte script and what effect these had on the finished film.
In this 2016 piece, filmmaker and professor of French Samba Gadjigo (SEMBENE!) characterizes what defines the work of Ousmane Sembène.
In this 2013 interview, shot in Toronto, “Fangoria” editor in chief Chris Alexander talks to actors Art Hindle and Cindy Hinds about THE BROOD.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): NIGHT ON EARTH Commentary: Los Angeles
Description: Recorded in 2007, this audio commentary features director of photography Frederick Elmes and location sound mixer Drew Kunin.

This 2013 visual essay sets clips from A MAN ESCAPED to a reading of “Functions of Film Sound,” a chapter from David Bordwell and Kristin Thompson’s book “Film Art.” The chapter analyzes the sound design of A MAN ESCAPED as a means of discussing the use of sound in film. The text is read by actor Dan Stewart.
In this audio excerpt from an interview conducted in 1963, Alfred Hitchcock talks to filmmaker Peter Bogdanovich about his early years as a director.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): All the Boys Are Called Patrick
Description: Directed by Jean-Luc Godard • 1957 • France /  / A man makes dates with two women on the same day without realizing that they are best friends. Directed by Jean-Luc Godard.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Jon Else on THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK
Description: In this 2011 program, filmmaker Jon Else, director of the UC Berkeley documentary program, takes a closer look at director Robert Epstein’s THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK.
On September 22, 1994, just over a year before his death, THE LOVERS director Louis Malle was interviewed by journalist Angelika Wittlich at his office in Paris.

Actor Barbara Sukowa began her career in the German theater. In this 2003 interview she discusses her move into film under the direction of Rainer Werner Fassbinder. In 1981, Sukowa starred in Fassbinder’s LOLA, as well as Margarethe von Trotta’s MARIANNE AND JULIANE. She has since worked with Lars von Trier, Michael Cimino, and David Cronenberg.
This interview with actor Édgar Ramírez was shot in Tenerife, Spain, in June 2011.
In this 2009 interview, director Costa-Gavras recalls Greece’s volatile post–World War II era, the making of Z, and the film’s timely release.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Bibi Andersson, Ingmar Bergman, and Liv Ullmann
Description: In the following excerpt from an interview originally recorded for Swedish television in 1966, PERSONA’s director and lead actors discuss the evolution of the film and their individual interpretations of it.
This introduction to THE MARSEILLE TRILOGY by filmmaker Bertrand Tavernier was recorded in Paris in 2017.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Mike Figgis on THE BROWNING VERSION
Description: New video interview with Mike Figgis, director of the 1994 remake.
In this interview, LORD OF THE FLIES cameraman and editor Gerald Feil examines specific scenes from the film and discusses some of the technical obstacles that arose during production.
Directed by Chris Marker • 1956 • France /  / Chris Marker's documentary on Peking offers his thoughts on the people, culture and history of the city.

Directed by Agnès Varda • 1967 • France /  /  /  / In her effervescent first California film, Agnès Varda delves into her own family history. The short documentary UNCLE YANCO features Varda tracking down a Greek emigrant relative she’s never met, discovering an artist and kindred soul leading a bohemian life in Sausalito. /  /  /  / Restored by the Cineteca di Bologna at L’Immagine Ritrovata in association with Ciné-Tamaris and The Film Foundation. Restoration funding provided by the Annenberg Foundation, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (LACMA) and The Film Foundation.

In 1959 Hiroshi Teshigahara shot the following 16 mm footage of he and his father’s first trip to Barcelona and the outlying Catalonian countryside, including a visit to the home of Salvador Dali in Port Lligat. The footage was recorded without sound.

As undersecretary of state to President John F. Kennedy, George Ball was an early opponent of America’s military involvement in Vietnam. In Lyndon B. Johnson’s administration, he was one of the few advisers to argue against the U.S.’s escalation of the war. He resigned in 1966. In these excerpts, he discusses his roles in both administrations.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Jane Shattuc on EIGHT HOURS DON’T MAKE A DAY
Description: The following interview with Jane Shattuc, professor of visual and media arts at Emerson College and author of “Television, Tabloids, and Tears: Fassbinder and Popular Culture,” was conducted in June 2018.

Directed by Carroll Ballard • 1969 • United States /  / This twenty-minute documentary from 1969 follows champion bull rider Larry Mahan as he competes in the 1968 National Rodeo Finals in Oklahoma City.
The following video essay about PITFALL, by James Quandt of the TIFF Cinematheque, was recorded in 2007.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): David Allen Appreciation: THE MAGIC TREASURE
Description: EQUINOX’s effects animator, David Allen, was a revered figure within the effects and stop-motion animation community until his untimely death, in 1999. Presented here is piece of his best and rarest work: a puppet-animated fairy tale called THE MAGIC TREASURE.
This 2008 video interview with Tadao Sato (“Currents in Japanese Cinema”) features the renowned film historian’s insightful observations on the social and cinematic resonance of TWENTY-FOUR EYES.
Directed by Hal Roach • 1919 •  /  / After a wild bachelor party, a boy finds himself aboard a sailing vessel where he encounters numerous adventures in this short film.

Conducted in 2002, this interview features IL POSTO writer-director Ermanno Olmi reminiscing about the film and his career. Film critic (and occasional Olmi collaborator) Tullio Kezich also offers his thoughts.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Emmanuelle Riva on HIROSHIMA MON AMOUR
Description: In the first of these two interviews, actor Emmanuelle Riva speaks with François Chalais on the occasion of the debut of HIROSHIMA MON AMOUR, in which she had her first starring role, at the 1959 Cannes Film Festival. In the second, shot in 2003, she sits down with the Criterion Collection to discuss the film.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Errol Morris on GATES OF HEAVEN
Description: This interview with director Errol Morris was conducted in Cambridge, Massachusetts, in October 2014.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Raoul Coutard on JULES AND JIM
Description: Cinematographer Raoul Coutard shot films for many of the French New Wave’s most celebrated directors, including Jean-Luc Godard and François Truffaut. In this 2003 interview in Paris, he recalls his work on JULES AND JIM.

In F FOR FAKE, director Orson Welles uses excerpts from a 1972 press conference that Howard Hughes conducted, by telephone, in order to discredit the Clifford Irving “autobiography” of him. In the following piece, audio of Hughes’s answers is accompanied by text of the reporters’ questions.

BAD TIMING marked the first time Theresa Russell worked with director Nicolas Roeg, whom she later married. In this interview, recorded in Los Angeles, in January 2005, she discusses the film and its impact on her life.

Charlie Chaplin long wanted to make a film about Napoleon Bonaparte, working and reworking his concept over a number of years—until ultimately it morphed into THE GREAT DICTATOR. The following visual essay by Cecilia Cenciarelli, archivist and head of the Cineteca di Bologna’s Progetto Chaplin, traces the trajectory of Chaplin’s Napoleon project.
The following nineteen minutes of footage offer a behind-the-scenes look at the audio postsync sessions for THE PIANO TEACHER and feature director Michael Haneke and actor Isabelle Huppert.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Visual Effects in THE GOLD RUSH
Description: In this 2012 interview, visual effects expert Craig Barron looks at the techniques used to create some of the classic set pieces in THE GOLD RUSH.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Jane Campion: The Film School Years
Description: This conversation between critic Peter Thompson and Jane Campion took place in 1989, following the success of Campion’s short films. It was produced for the Australian Television Radio and Film School, where she studied.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): The Art of Effects: THE GOLD RUSH
Description: This installment of our ongoing series on special effects focuses on the techniques used to create some of the classic set pieces in Charlie Chaplin’s groundbreaking 1925 film THE GOLD RUSH.
Recorded in 2007, this audio commentary features director of photography Frederick Elmes and location sound mixer Drew Kunin.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Jackie Coogan: The First Child Star
Description: The following video essay by Charlie Chaplin scholar Lisa Haven, on THE KID actor Jackie Coogan, was produced in 2015.

This interview with PURPLE NOON writer Patricia Highsmith, conducted by Agnès Thierre and Pierre Lambert and directed by Lambert, first aired on the French television program “Variances” on August 3, 1971.

In this video program, produced in 2006, actors Ruby Dee and James Earl Jones and filmmaker William Greaves recall Paul Robeson, his impact on African-American culture, and the controversy that plagued his final years.
The following commentary features music historian Peter Guralnick and was recorded in Boston in the winter of 2002. This commentary is a song-by-song reading of the film.
The following commentary features music historian Peter Guralnick and was recorded in Boston in the winter of 2002. This commentary is a look at Otis’s career, pre- and post-Monterey.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Tsutomu Yamazaki on HIGH AND LOW
Description: The following interview with award-winning actor Tsutomu Yamazaki, who plays the kidnapper, Takeuchi, in HIGH AND LOW, was recorded in Tokyo in 2008.

Director: D. A. Pennebaker and Chris Hegedus
Description: Directed by D. A. Pennebaker and Chris Hegedus • 1986 • United States /  / Redding, a venerable star of Memphis's Stax record label, seduced the "love crowd" in one of his best, and last, performances. Shake! Otis at Monterey, feature the entire set of this legendary musician, a performance that has entered rock-and-roll mythology.

In this interview with George Sluizer, conducted at his home in France in May 2014, the director discusses the challenges of adapting THE VANISHING from its source novel, the psychology of its characters, and his approach to building suspense.
Cinematographer Raoul Coutard recalls working with director Jean-Luc Godard on WEEKEND.
In this 2018 program, critic, filmmaker, and festival programmer Tony Rayns discusses director Lino Brocka, MANILA IN THE CLAWS OF LIGHT, and the social context in which the film was made.
In this 2013 visual essay, Jacques Tati scholar Stéphane Goudet explores the director’s stylistic choices in PLAYTIME.

Conducted in 2002, this interview features I FIDANZATI writer/director Ermanno Olmi reminiscing about the film and his career. Film critic/historian (and occasional Olmi collaborator) Tullio Kezich also offers his thoughts.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Donna Deitch and Jane Lynch on DESERT HEARTS
Description: Wanting to make a film about a lesbian relationship that didn’t end in tragedy, director Donna Deitch spent five years working on DESERT HEARTS. Its release in 1985 was a landmark moment in queer cinema. In this conversation, recorded in Los Angeles in 2017, Deitch and actor Jane Lynch discuss the making of the film and its significance for Lynch.

After a much-publicized but brief stint in Hollywood, Jean Seberg was selected by Jean-Luc Godard to star in BREATHLESS. It was to become the legendary actress’s best-remembered role. This 2007 video essay by Mark Rappaport, director of the 1995 film FROM THE JOURNALS OF JEAN SEBERG, reveals the true story behind her iconic face.
In this 2013 interview, visual effects expert Craig Barron looks at the creation of some of FOREIGN CORRESPONDENT’s thrilling set pieces.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Tadao Sato on THE ONLY SON
Description: This interview with Japanese film critic and scholar Tadao Sato was conducted in November 2003 in Tokyo.

This short 1966 documentary about the making of ANDREI RUBLEV is a project by Dina Musatova, who had studied at the film school VGIK with director Andrei Tarkovsky. This film is held by the Russian State Documentary Film & Photo Archive in Krasnogorsk.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Abbas Kiarostami on TASTE OF CHERRY
Description: Dr. Jamsheed Akrami, professor of communication at William Paterson University, conducted this interview with director Abbas Kiarostami prior to the release of TASTE OF CHERRY, in 1997. It was recorded for Dr. Akrami’s 2000 documentary on Iranian cinema, FRIENDLY PERSUASION.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): B. Ruby Rich and José Antonio Évora
Description: This program features interview with film critics B. Ruby Rich and José Antonio Évora. They were recorded in San Francisco and Miami in 2018.
The celebrated actor Liv Ullmann appeared in ten of Ingmar Bergman’s films. In this 2013 interview, conducted in New York, she discusses their work together.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Chen Chang on A BRIGHTER SUMMER DAY
Description: Taiwanese actor Chen Chang was only a teenager when he got the lead role in A BRIGHTER SUMMER DAY. He would go on to become a major star, appearing in such films as HAPPY TOGETHER; CROUCHING TIGER, HIDDEN DRAGON; and THE GRANDMASTER. In this 2014 interview, Chang discusses his breakthrough debut.
The Pulitzer Prize–winning author on a lifetime of moviegoing

Directed by Louis Malle • 1962 • France /  / In his short documentary Vive le Tour, Louis Malle presents his energetic evocation of the Tour de France. This, Humain, trop humain, and Place de la République, Louis Malle's three French-set documentaries, reveal, in an eclectic array of ways, the director's eternal fascination with, and respect for, the everyday lives of everyday people.
Director Vilgot Sjoman made “Selft Portrait ’92” for Swedish television. Presented here are excerpts from this program, selected and edited for this release by the director.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Dudley Andrew on THE LIFE OF OHARU
Description: This 2013 illustrated audio essay, written and narrated by film scholar Dudley Andrew, explores director Kenji Mizoguchi’s interest in the theater, art, and fiction of seventeenth- and eighteenth-century Japan, and locates the roots of his idea for the adaptation THE LIFE OF OHARU in his second postwar film, UTAMARO AND HIS FIVE WOMEN.
This 2017 interview with film scholar James Steffen (“The Cinema of Sergei Parajanov”) addresses the making of THE COLOR OF POMEGRANATES.
The author of “Lit” and “The Liars’ Club” on a lifetime of moviegoing
Director Francesco Rosi and film critic Tullio Kezich, who chronicled the production of SALVATORE GIULIANO, discuss the filmmaker's start in cinema and his touchstone film, in this 2003 program.
The following is a 2014 interview with RIDE IN THE WHIRLWIND director Monte Hellman and assistant director Gary Kurtz.
Phil Walden was Otis Redding’s manager from 1959 until Redding’s death in 1967. This interview was recorded in Atlanta in the spring of 2002.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): 24 Hours in the Life of a Clown
Description: Directed by Jean-Pierre Melville • 1946 • France /  / Jean-Pierre Melville's first directorial effort was this 1946 short film about a clown and his partner, who find inspiration one day in the streets for their performance in the circus that night.

“Melville on Melville,” Rui Nogueira’s 1971 book of interviews with Jean-Pierre Melville, was for decades the only English-language work devoted to the director’s films. In 2003, cinema historian Ginette Vincendeau added “Jean-Pierre Melville, An American in Paris.” In this 2005 video interview, Vincendeau shares her thoughts on LE SAMOURAÏ.

Directed by Adrian Sitaru • 2014 • Romania /  / After a casting session, two filmmakers found the perfect 14-year-old girl to star in their new movie. Now, they have to convince the reluctant mother to let her daughter play the role of a sexually abused child. What follows is a witty argumentation on proper parenting and on the abuses and sacrifices made in the name of great works of art.

In the following interview, conducted in February 2017, film scholar David Bordwell analyzes the evolution of director Yasujiro Ozu’s style by comparing the 1932 silent film I WAS BORN, BUT . . . with the filmmaker’s own 1959 reworking of the story, GOOD MORNING.
The author of “The Feral Detective” on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): And the Whole Sky Fit in the Dead Cow's Eye
Description: Directed by Francisca Alegría • 2016 • Chile /  / Emeteria (85) is visited by the ghost of her patrón, Teodoro. She believes he has come to take her to the afterlife, but he has more devastating news.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Murray Melvin on A TASTE OF HONEY
Description: Murray Melvin’s performance as Geoffrey in A TASTE OF HONEY brought him international acclaim, including the award for best actor at the 1962 Cannes Film Festival. In this interview, recorded in London in May 2016, Melvin (who also originated his role in the play) discusses the film’s production.
Directed by Eric Rohmer • 1958 • France /  / In this short film from director Eric Rohmer, Véronique tutors a perplexing young boy.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Stig Björkman on INGRID BERGMAN: IN HER OWN WORDS
Description: Director Stig Björkman comments on the making of INGRID BERGMAN: IN HER OWN WORDS in this 2016 interview.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Jérémie Renier and Olivier Gourmet on LA PROMESSE
Description: The following 2012 program features interviews with actors Jérémie Renier and Olivier Gourmet.

Directed by Charles Chaplin • 1919 • United States /  / Charlie Chaplin stars in this comedy short about a middle class family man who encounters one difficulty after another while attempting to make a simple excursion by car and boat with his wife and kids.
This short documentary about DRY WOOD and HOT PEPPER, in 2014, features interviews with Maureen Gosling, Les Blank’s collaborator on the films; Blank’s son beau; and filmmaker Taylor Hackford.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Lasse Hallström on MY LIFE AS A DOG
Description: This interview with director Lasse Hallström was recorded in the spring of 2002.
In this piece, produced in the fall of 2014, LA CIÉNAGA director Lucrecia Martel examines her inspirations and approach to cinema.

Directed by Zofia Kowalewska • 2016 • Poland /  /  /  / A Polish couple on the cusp of celebrating their forty-fifth anniversary confronts still-fresh emotional wounds in this tender documentary exploration of commitment, betrayal, and forgiveness.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Jacqueline Bisset on UNDER THE VOLCANO
Description: The role of Yvonne in John Huston’s UNDER THE VOLCANO remains one of the high points in acclaimed actress Jacqueline Bisset’s career. The following video interview was recorded in June 2007 in Los Angeles.

In this 2011 interview, film critic Adriano Aprà discusses how, in EUROPE ’51, director Roberto Rossellini was working in a more didactic mode than in his earlier films, one that anticipated his later television work.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Lois Sutcliffe Smith on Lindsay Anderson
Description: Lois Sutcliffe Smith, who gave THIS SPORTING LIFE director Lindsay Anderson his first opportunity in filmmaking with MEET THE PIONEERS, remained a close friend of Lindsay’s. This video interview with Smith was recorded in March 2007 in London.

Directed by François Truffaut • 1957 • France /  / The story takes place in provincial France, where a group of young boys ("mistons" roughly translates "brats") are infatuated with a beautiful young woman. Jealous of her passionate affair, they conspire to make mischief for the woman and her boyfriend.
This conversation between New Wave directors François Truffaut and Eric Rohmer, titled “Postface à L’ATALANTE,” was presented following a 1968 French television broadcast of the film.

In this 18-minute piece, produced in June 2013, cowriter-director Noah Baumbach, director of photography Sam Levy, and Pascal Dangin, who did the film’s color mastering, discuss digital filmmaking, the late cinematographer Harry Savides, and how they achieved the look of FRANCES HA.

Directed by Andrew Haigh • 2009 • United Kingdom /  / An adolescent girl meets a boy while on holiday with her cousins. This short film, created in 2009 by Andrew Haigh, provides some insight into the director’s evolving vision.
A portrait of England during World War II, this short propaganda film is considered a landmark in nonfiction filmmaking for its deft montage and visual poetry.
The director of THE UNBEARABLE LIGHTNESS OF BEING on a lifetime of moviegoing

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Rita Tushingham on A TASTE OF HONEY
Description: Rita Tushingham’s performance as Jo in A TASTE OF HONEY brought her international acclaim, including the award for best actress at the 1962 Cannes Film Festival. In this interview, recorded in London in May 2016, Tushingham discusses the film’s production.
The following program was broadcast nationally on September 23, 1952.
This program with MYSTERIOUS OBJECT AT NOON director Apichatpong Weerasethakul was produced in 2017.

The son of Jean Renoir and the grandson of Pierre-Auguste Renoir, Alain Renoir worked as an assistant cameraman on two of his father’s films—LA BÊTE HUMAINE and THE RULES OF THE GAME—before coming to the United States and embarking on a career as a professor of comparative literature. This interview took place at his home in California in 2003.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Zbigniew Zamachowski and Julie Delpy on WHITE
Description: In this program, produced in 2011, Polish actor Zbigniew Zamachowski and French actor Julie Delpy share their memories about the making of WHITE and discuss their admiration for director Krzysztof Kieślowski.

Director Mike Leigh dramatized Gilbert and Sullivan’s creation of “The Mikado” in his award-winning 1999 film TOPSY-TURVY, which required extensive research on the duo and the opera. In this video interview, recorded in 2010, Leigh brings his unique perspective to the 1939 film version of the opera.
The following interview on THE MAGIC FLUTE with film scholar Peter Cowie, author of “Ingmar Bergman: A Critical Biography,” was produced in 2018.
The actor and comedian on a lifetime of moviegoing
Directed by Krzysztof Kieślowski • 1970 • Poland /  /  /  / Krzysztof Kieślowski began his career making documentaries. Presented here is FACTORY, one of his nonfiction shorts.
The following is a 2010 interview with actor Willem Dafoe.

In the following interview, produced in 2015, Polish film critic Tadeusz Sobolewski considers the political context of Krzysztof Kieślowski’s BLIND CHANCE, the film’s censorship and delayed release, and its significance within Kieślowski’s body of work.

Directed by Clu Gulager • 1969 • United States /  / Directed by character actor Clu Gulager and shot by cinematographer Laszlo Kovacs, this 1969 short film was an influence on David Gordon Green's GEORGE WASHINGTON.
In this new visual essay, film scholar and Bergman biographer Peter Cowie traces the influence of Victor Sjöström and THE PHANTOM CARRIAGE on the films of Ingmar Bergman.

Directed by Suzan Pitt • 1979 • United States /  / Suzan Pitt's animated short throws open the doors of perception onto a shape-shifting vision of polymorphous sexuality. A landmark in the history of independent animation, ASPARAGUS is a mesmerizing exploration of the artist's inner world, and a viewing experience like no other.
The following 18 minutes of silent, black-and-white footage was shot during the production of PERSONA. It is presented here with audio commentary by Ingmar Bergman scholar Birgitta Steene.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): MERRY CHRISTMAS MR. LAWRENCE: On the Music
Description: In this interview, conducted in New York in 2010, actor and composer Ryuichi Sakamoto discusses the score for MERRY CHRISTMAS MR. LAWRENCE.

In this 2011 documentary, activist Susie Bright, author of “Big Sex, Little Death,” and UC Berkeley professor Linda Williams, author of “Screening Sex,” discuss BELLE DE JOUR’s representation of feminine sexuality and fantasy, and its themes of masochism, power, and desire, in terms of director Luis Buñuel’s surrealist aesthetic.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Adriano Apra on THE FLOWERS OF ST. FRANCIS
Description: Filmed in Rome in 2004, this interview features film historian Adriano Apra.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): BLACK ORPHEUS and That Bossa Nova Sound!
Description: BLACK ORPHEUS introduced an international audience to the sights and sounds of Rio de Janeiro. In the following program, produced in 2010, jazz historian Gary Giddins and Brazilian author Ruy Castro recall the roots of the film’s score and the role it played in popularizing the bossa nova sound.
The following introduction to TRANCES by filmmaker Martin Scorsese, founder of the World Cinema Project, was produced in 2013.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Hou Hsiao-hsien and Edmond Wong on TAIPEI STORY
Description: This conversation between filmmakers Hou Hsiao-hsien (who plays the main character in TAIPEI STORY and cowrote the script) and Edmond Wong was produced in 2017.
This silent 16 mm reel includes never-before-seen raw footage and alternate takes that were not used in NIGHT OF THE LIVING DEAD.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Jeanne Moreau on ELEVATOR TO THE GALLOWS
Description: This interview with actor Jeanne Moreau was recorded at the Brasserie La Lorraine in Paris in 2005.
This piece combines 1964 interviews with the Beatles with behind-the-scenes footage and photos.

Renée Shafransky collaborated with Spalding Gray on a number of the latter’s monologues, including “Swimming to Cambodia,” “Monster in a Box,” and “Gray’s Anatomy.” In this interview, conducted in New York in March 2012, she discusses their process.

The following is a 2013 interview with filmmaker and Japanese-culture scholar John Nathan, who shares his memories of actor and filmmaker Shintaro Katsu, star of the ZATOICHI series.
The following interview with actor Arno Frisch was recorded in Berlin in December 2018.
This 18-minute opening sequence was included only in an early, 183-minute edit of FACES that was screened in Toronto in April 1968.

Filmmaker, writer, and educator Jean-Pierre Gorin began his career as Jean-Luc Godard’s collaborator on the Dziga Vertov Group films, including TOUT VA BIEN. In this interview, recorded in 2005, he discusses his friend director Chris Marker and SANS SOLEIL.
In this 2016 interview, Jan-Christopher Horak, director of the UCLA Film & Television Archive, discusses the importance of WESTFRONT 1918 to director G. W. Pabst’s career.
This interview with director Steve McQueen was conducted in 2009.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Fritz Rasp on THE THREEPENNY OPERA
Description: Film historian Hans-Michael Bock filmed this interview with THE THREEPENNY OPERA star Fritz Rasp in 1972.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Greil Marcus and D. A. Pennebaker on DONT LOOK BACK
Description: This conversation between music journalist and cultural critic Greil Marcus and director D. A. Pennebaker about DONT LOOK BACK was filmed in 2010.

Actor-director Harold Lloyd’s archive contains over a hundred hours of personal home movies. Here, his granddaughter Suzanne Lloyd narrates a selection of footage shot around the time that SPEEDY was made.
Film historian Peter Hames has written extensively on Central and Eastern European cinema. The following interview with him about MARKETA LAZAROVÁ was conducted in London in 2013.
ALL AT SEA is a home movie by Alistair Cooke featuring Chaplin and actress Paulette Goddard, presented with a score by Donald Sosin.
In this video essay, created in 2017, art historian Steven Jacobs explores the roles that architecture, space, and setting play in THE LODGER.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Guillermo del Toro on THE MAN WHO KNEW TOO MUCH
Description: This interview with filmmaker Guillermo del Toro, a dedicated fan of director Alfred Hitchcock and the author of the 1990 book “Alfred Hitchcock,” was conducted in 2012.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Ronald Neame on THE HORSE’S MOUTH

Description: In this interview with Jean Cocteau, taken from an episode of the French television series “In Search of Jazz,” the director talks about the music in his films. The program first aired on April 24, 1956.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Tatsuya Nakadai on THE HUMAN CONDITION
Description: In this new video interview with Tatsuya Nakadai, conducted in 2009, the screen legend discusses his landmark role as Kaji in THE HUMAN CONDITION.

In this introduction, recorded in Hollywood in April 2005, director Todd Haynes reflects on the masterful filmmaking of LE PLAISIR. Please note: this interview contains remarks about the ending of the film.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): I Put A Spell On Me
Description: The following are excerpts from the 2001 documentary SCREAMIN’ JAY HAWKINS: I PUT A SPELL ON ME.
This 2010 documentary visits MYSTERY TRAIN’s locations and discusses the rich social and musical history of Memphis.
In this interview, recorded in 2011, Andrew Robinson, author of “Satyajit Ray: The Inner Eye,” discusses the making of THE MUSIC ROOM and the film’s cultural significance.
In this 2010 interview, director Guillermo del Toro offers his thoughts on CRONOS, including what the film means to him and its place in his diverse career.
In this new video essay, David Cairns examines Yasujiro Ozu’s use of humor in his films.
Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1968 • France /  / Diatoms are explored through microscopic footage while their purpose and uses are explained.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): My Old Fiddle: A Visit with Tommy Jarrell in the Blue Ridge
Description: This seventeen-minute film, composed of footage shot during the making of SPROUT WINGS AND FLY, continues the story of Tommy Jarrell and reveals the origins of his famous fiddle.

Directed by Hollis Frampton • 1966 • United States /  / The film has the look of a New York loft, a certain overlay of gritty, claustrophobic funk that permeated that whole period. It's also a formalist's snapshot album. Those people were friends of mine during a fairly interesting time. We were all lepers, 'out-of-it,' or what have you, with the possible exception of Larry Poons.' , Hollis Frampton

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Shih Chun on A TOUCH OF ZEN
Description: In this new piece, actor Shih Chun addresses his longtime collaboration with director King Hu and his performance as Gu Sheng-zhai in A TOUCH OF ZEN.
In this 2006 interview, filmmaker Bertrand Tavernier recalls his friend the director Michael Powell and Powell’s stories about the making of BLACK NARCISSUS.

The following interview with Eric Rentschler, a film historian and the Arthur Kingsley Porter Professor of Germanic languages and literature at Harvard University, was conducted in Cambridge, Massachusetts, in November 2017.
In this 2008 video essay, writer Tag Gallagher analyzes director Max Ophuls’s use of montage to create moments of passion and desire in his films, particularly THE EARRINGS OF MADAME DE . . .

Suzanne Lloyd is the granddaughter of Harold Lloyd and was raised by him and his wife, Mildred Davis Lloyd, in Los Angeles. She is the president of Harold Lloyd Entertainment and has dedicated her career to preserving and promoting Harold’s film legacy. In this 2013 introduction, she discusses SAFETY LAST! and its place in his career.
The following program, recorded in Tokyo in 2008, features interviews with EMPIRE OF PASSION actors Kazuko Yoshiyuki and Tatsuya Fuji, who play Seki and Toyoji.

Award-winning composer Georges Delerue wrote scores for more than 200 films—in addition to composing operas, ballets, chamber pieces, and more. He is perhaps best known for the eleven films he scored for François Truffaut. This audio essay, written by music historian Jeff Smith, explores Delerue’s music for SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Five Directors on THE BATTLE OF ALGIERS
Description: In this collection of interviews conducted in 2004, directors Spike Lee, Mira Nair, Julian Schnabel, Steven Soderbergh, and Oliver Stone discuss the influence, style, and importance of Gillo Pontecorvo’s film THE BATTLE OF ALGIERS.

Directed by Lily Baldwin • 2016 • United States /  /  /  / What if the ideal life you've meticulously constructed isn’t enough? Your swallowed truths, buried longings, become a parasite that lives off you, in you, with you. It’s a nagging reminder of the unrequited; a codependent affair. This breaking point is the film SWALLOWED. Sam, newly a mother, shops at a supermarket with her baby and husband Carlson. She throws a neighborhood shishkabob party in her den. Her family shares a Sunday breakfast. But through her smiles and picturesque tasks, there's a suppression. Sam’s grown something she can no longer contain. As she purges this parasite, we move inside her body and experience this wildness as a feverish dance.The parasite ejects us back into the kitchen of another woman, alone eating breakfast as she looks at a happy couple pictured on the back of her cereal box. It’s Sam and Carlson. What's beneath a picture? A dream within a dream. Horror meets dance, SWALLOWED suggests a complex truth to motherhood and domesticity.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Tatsuya Fuji on IN THE REALM OF THE SENSES
Description: This interview with actor Tatsuya Fuji was conducted in 2009.

In the nineteenth century, writer Lafcadio Hearn played a crucial role in popularizing Japanese folklore for Western audiences. Four of his stories provided the basis for Masaki Kobayashi’s KWAIDAN. In this piece, made in 2015, English literature scholar Christopher Benfey, editor of “Lafcadio Hearn: American Writings,” profiles Hearn.

À NOS AMOURS was actor Sandrine Bonnaire’s feature debut. She went on to work with such filmmakers as Claude Chabrol and Jacques Rivette. In this interview, recorded in 2003, she describes her lasting on- and offscreen relationship with director Maurice Pialat.

Directed by Chris Lavis and Maciek Szczerbowski • 2007 • Canada /  / This stop-motion animated film takes viewers on an exhilarating existential journey into the fully imagined, tactile world of Madame Tutli-Putli. As she travels alone on the night train, weighed down with all her earthly possessions and the ghosts of her past, she faces both the kindness and menace of strangers. Finding herself caught up in a desperate metaphysical adventure, adrift between real and imagined worlds, Madame Tutli-Putli confronts her demons.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Akira Mizuta Lippit on THE NAKED ISLAND
Description: The following interview with film scholar Akira Mizuta Lippit was conducted in Los Angeles in February 2016.

Directed by Agnieszka Smoczyńska • 2010 • Poland /  /  /  / This short documentary about opera singer Maria Fołtyn was directed by Agnieszka Smoczyńska in 2010, while she was a film student at the Wajda School in Warsaw.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Emily Watson on BREAKING THE WAVES
Description: In the following interview, conducted in London in June 2013, Emily Watson discusses the challenges she faced in playing the complicated character Bess in BREAKING THE WAVES.

Directed by Mike Leigh • 1987 • United Kingdom /  /  /  / David Thewlis and Alison Steadman star in this 1987 short comedy by Mike Leigh about a romance between a hairdresser’s daughter and a young man who communicates only through one-liners.
During the production of his 1975 film BLACK MOON, Louis Malle was interviewed for Canadian television about his unusual start in filmmaking and his first feature, ELEVATOR TO THE GALLOWS.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Ginette Vincendeau on LE SILENCE DE LA MER
Description: In this interview, conducted in November 2014, film professor Ginette Vincendeau, author of “Jean-Pierre Melville: An American in Paris,” discusses Melville’s remarkable film debut.
The following footage is excerpted from “Chantal Akerman par Chantal Akerman,” a 1997 episode of the French television program “Cinéma, de notre temps.”

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): David Lynch and Frederick Elmes on ERASERHEAD
Description: This interview with director David Lynch and cinematographer Frederick Elmes was shot in 1979 by filmmaker Tom Christie for his television production class at UCLA. It takes place at one of ERASERHEAD's locations in Los Angeles, where the Beverly Center shopping mall now stands.
A piece on Richard Lester's methods.
The following is a 2014 interview with RIDE IN THE WHIRLWIND director Monte Hellman and chief wrangler Calvin Johnson.
Directed by Mikhail Vartanov, this rarely screened impressionistic documentary from 1969 features footage of director Sergei Parajanov making THE COLOR OF POMEGRANATES.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): President Nixon’s Farewell to the White House Staff
Description: The following was broadcast live on August 9, 1974, from the East Room of the White House.

In this interview, conducted in April 2013, sociology professor Priscilla Parkhurst Ferguson, the author of “Accounting for Taste: The Triumph of French Cuisine,” discusses the importance of cuisine to the French national identity, and its poignant evocation in BABETTE’S FEAST.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Sarah Polley and Greta Gerwig on FRANCES HA
Description: The following conversation between actor and filmmaker Sarah Polley and the film’s cowriter and star, Greta Gerwig, was recorded in Toronto in July 2013.

In this exclusive documentary, director Andrzej Wajda and longtime Polish film critic Jerzy Plazeski talk about the making of DANTON, the reaction of the French, and interpretations of the film as a statement on Polish politics and Solidarity movement.
Directed by Edwige Shaki • 1999 • France /  / An artist falls for an art model who reminds him of a sculpture.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Behind the Scenes of WILD STRAWBERRIES
Description: The following 16 minutes of silent footage was filmed by director Ingmar Bergman on the set of WILD STRAWBERRIES. It features voice-over by Jan Wengström, curator of archival film collections at the Swedish Film Institute.
In this video interview, conducted in 2011, renowned Japanese-film critic Tadao Sato offers his insights on the cinematic accomplishments and cultural significance of KURONEKO

The following interviews, conducted in 2003, feature screenwriter Suso Cecchi d'Amico, film writers Laura Delli Colli and Lino Micciche, cinematographer Giuseppe Rotunno, and costume designer Piero Tosi discussing Luchino Visconti and the evolution of LE NOTTI BIANCHE’s production—from costume design to actor auditions.

Film historian and teacher Adriano Aprà has devoted much of his career to Roberto Rossellini and his films, directing the 1992 film ROSSELLINI VISTO DA ROSSELLINI, editing the 1992 collection of Rossellini essays and interviews “My Method,” and writing the 2006 book “In viaggio con Rossellini.” In this 2009 interview, Aprà discusses PAISAN.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Harry Baer on FOX AND HIS FRIENDS
Description: This interview with actor Harry Baer was conducted in Berlin in September 2016.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Melvüt Akkaya on LAW OF THE BORDER
Description: This interview with filmmaker Melvüt Akkaya was produced in 2017.

In this 2008 discussion, film critic Camille Taboulay, psychoanalysts Lucille Durrmeyer and Jean-Claude Polack, and seventeenth-century literature specialist Liliane Picciola talk about DONKEY SKIN’s themes of incest, love, and childhood fantasy.
In this 2010 visual essay, Chaplin historian Jeffrey Vance, author of “Chaplin: Genius of the Cinema,” draws from a wealth of production photography to discuss the making of MODERN TIMES.

In this conversation, recorded in Stockholm in 2003, film historian Peter Cowie and writer Jörn Donner discuss Ingmar Bergman’s 1955 return to Svensk Filmindustri and his subsequent breakthrough comedy success, SMILES OF A SUMMER NIGHT.

This 2005 documentary about various collaborators’ experiences working with Lars von Trier features interviews with costume designer Manon Rasmussen, film school teacher Mogens Rukov, editor-director Tomas Gislason, producer Peter Aalbaek Jensen, art director Peter Grant, actor Michael Simpson, production manager Per Arman, and actor Ole Ernst.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Madhabi Mukherjee and Soumitra Chatterjee on CHARULATA
Description: This interview program features actors Madhabi Mukherjee and Soumitra Chatterjee, who play Charulata and Amal in CHARULATA. The interviews were conducted in Kolkata in 2013.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Nathalie Baye on EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF
Description: In this interview from 2010, actor Nathalie Baye describes Jean-Luc Godard’s directing style and the premiere of EVERY MAN FOR HIMSELF at Cannes.

Is LES ENFANTS TERRIBLES a film by Jean-Pierre Melville or Jean Cocteau? In this short 2003 piece, director Noël Simsolo poses that question to film scholar Dominique Païni and critic Jean Narboni while strolling through an exhibition of Cocteau’s work at the Centre Pompidou, in Paris.

Although SOLARIS was occasionally marketed as the Soviet 2001, director Andrei Tarkovsky actually thought of his film as 2001’s polar opposite—it emphasized humanity and morality over special effects and science fiction. For the creation of SOLARIS’s distinctive look, Tarkovsky turned to art director Mikhail Romadin, interviewed here in 2011.

Directed by Chris Shepherd • 2010 • United Kingdom /  / Blues rinses, portraits of the queen and stand up bingo. Chris Shepherd delves into his past and recalls the world of his Aunty Glad and her local Conservative Club. The hues of blue that make up the Tory heartland are more than just a party - they are a state of mind.

Director: François Alaux, Hervé de Crécy, and Ludovic Houplain
Description: Directed by François Alaux, Hervé de Crécy, and Ludovic Houplain • 2009 • France /  /  /  / Spectacular car chases, an intense hostage crisis, wild animals rampaging through the city, and even more in LOGORAMA!

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Jacques Tati at the 1972 San Francisco Film Festival
Description: In 1972, PLAYTIME made its U.S. debut at the San Francisco Film Festival. Director Jacques Tati attended the event and participated in a discussion about the film, moderated by program director Albert Johnson. The following are audio excerpts from that conversation.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Irène Jacob on THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE
Description: Irène Jacob was virtually unknown when she starred in THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE, for which she won the best actress award at Cannes. She has since appeared in such films as OTHELLO and THE SECRET GARDEN, and collaborated again with Krzysztof Kieślowski on RED (1994). In this 2005 interview, she discusses working on THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE.

The following deleted scenes reveal interesting details about the characters and the film's unique production design, costumes, and symbolism. Scenes 1-8 are presented with their original audio. Scenes 9-16 were missing their original audio and are therefore presented without sound.
1956 • Sweden /  / This short film covers the equestrian segment of the 1956 Summer Olympics.

In this video interview with Masahiro Shinoda, recorded in Tokyo in 2005, the director discusses his beginnings in filmmaking, the influence of such directors as Yasujiro Ozu and Kenji Mizoguchi on his work, and the style he used in SAMURAI SPY.

Directed by Adrian Sitaru • 2010 • Romania, Netherlands /  / When Mihaes's little boy brings home a sick dove this raises new conflicts between father and son, but also a possible 'reconciliation' that Mihaes does not want to lose.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Bernardo Bertolucci on LA COMMARE SECCA
Description: The following interview with director Bernardo Bertolucci was recorded in Rome in 2003. In it, he discusses his relationship with his mentor, filmmaker Pier Paolo Pasolini, and traces the development of LA COMMARE SECCA from preproduction to its debut at the 1962 Venice Film Festival.
In this interview, conducted in 2011, film critic Adriano Aprà examines both the themes of STROMBOLI and the media scandal that erupted during its production.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Madhabi Mukherjee on THE BIG CITY
Description: The following interview with actor Madhabi Mukherjee, who plays Arati in THE BIG CITY, was conducted in Calcutta in 2013.
The following 16-minute excerpt from Gerald Feil’s 1973 documentary THE EMPTY SPACE looks at some of Peter Brook’s methods as a theater director.
The following is sixteen minutes of outtakes and on-set footage from the shooting of ALICE IN THE CITIES. The material is silent but is presented here with music from CAN’s score for the film.

In 1937, director Michael Powell shot the feature THE EDGE OF THE WORLD on Scotland’s Isle of Foula. In 1978, Powell revisited the location for the documentary RETURN TO THE EDGE OF THE WORLD. This is a scene from THE EDGE OF THE WORLD, introduced by Powell himself in an excerpt from the documentary.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Nelson Rodríguez on MEMORIES OF UNDERDEVELOPMENT

Description: The following interview with Shampa Srivastava, who plays young Durga in PATHER PANCHALI (credited as Runki Banerjee), was conducted in 2015.

Directed by Annie Silverstein • 2014 • United States /  / Raised by a single mother on an isolated subdivision in rural Texas, fourteen-year-old Leila's deepest connection is with her pack of rescued dogs. On a hot summer morning, she wakes to find that her beloved pit bull Bubba has eviscerated a skunk. Leila heads to a nearby swimming hole to bathe him and meets Marco, a neighborhood boy with a chip on his shoulder. Charmed by his attention, Leila lets Marco into her world. But after a tense sexual encounter things spin out of control and Leila is forced to protect what she loves most at the cost of her own innocence.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Rade Serbedzija on BEFORE THE RAIN
Description: Rade Serbedzija was born in Croatia to an ethnic Derbian family and became one of the most popular Yugoslav actors of the 1970s and ’80s. In 1993, during the war in the former Yugoslavia, he fled to London, where Milcho Manchevski tracked him down to star in BEFORE THE RAIN. In this 2008 interview, he shares his thoughts about working on the film.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Bruce Eder on the Score to THINGS TO COME
Description: In this visual essay, produced in 2013, film historian Bruce Eder discusses Arthur Bliss’s musical score for THINGS TO COME.

This footage shows director David Lynch, actors Jack Nance and Charlotte Stewart, and director's assistant Catherine Coulson revisiting the locations at the AFI in Los Angeles where they made ERASERHEAD over the course of four years. The interviews were conducted by Toby Keeler for his 1997 documentary PRETTY AS A PICTURE: THE ART OF DAVID LYNCH.

The French-Brazilian-Italian coproduction BLACK ORPHEUS is often considered less a Brazilian film than one with a decidedly European perspective. In this 2010 interview, Brazilian film scholar Robert Stam discusses this criticism and BLACK ORPHEUS’s importance in film history.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Harold Lloyd: Big Man on Campus
Description: This 2014 visual essay by John Bengtson, author of “Silent Visions: Discovering Early Hollywood and New York Through the Films of Harold Lloyd,” looks at the locations used for the college and football scenes in THE FRESHMAN and features rare behind-the-scenes stills from Lloyd’s archive.

In the following interview, recorded in 2018 in New York, film programmer and Czechoslovak film expert Irena Kovarova discusses the importance of DIAMONDS OF THE NIGHT within the Czechoslovak New Wave.

The following interview with Harold Lloyd was broadcast on December 14, 1962, on Dutch public television. In it, Lloyd gives a tour of his estate and discusses his work and the development of his "Glasses Character."
Directed by Jérémy Comte • 2018 • Canada /  / Set in a surface mine, two boys sink into a seemingly innocent power game with Mother Nature as the sole observer.

In this interview, recorded in 2011, actor Irène Jacob discusses her experiences working with director Krzysztof Kieślowski (she also appeared in his film THE DOUBLE LIFE OF VÉRONIQUE), and talks about her and costar Jean-Louis Trintignant’s tightly choreographed performances in RED.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Jacques Demy at the Midnight Sun Film Festival
Description: In the following Q&A session from the 1987 Midnight Sun Film Festival in Sodankylä, Finland, director Jacques Demy sits down with moderator Peter von Bagh.

Directed by Jacques Tati • 1947 • France /  / This fifteen minute short, about a clumsy rural postman named Francois, was the first film Jacques Tati directed on his own; he also wrote and stars in it. Tati would reprise the role of Francois in Jour de Fete a few years later.
The following is actual footage of Spalding Gray’s macular surgery in the early 1990s. It is presented as it was filmed, without sound.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Kon Ichikawa on THE BURMESE HARP
Description: In the following interview, recorded in Japan in 2005, director Kon Ichikawa discusses the production of THE BURMESE HARP.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Passion Project: Martin Rosen on WATERSHIP DOWN
Description: Conducted in 2014, this interview with WATERSHIP DOWN writer, producer, and director Martin Rosen chronicles the difficult process of bringing Richard Adams’s celebrated novel to cinematic life.
In the following interview, recorded in October 2011, Noël Coward expert Barry Day, author of “Coward on Film: The Cinema of Noël Coward,” discusses BRIEF ENCOUNTER.

The working methods of director Jean Renoir, who was thought to have often used improvisation, were illuminated in 1994 when the Cinémathèque Française released UN TOURNAGE À LA CAMPAGNE, composed of eighty-nine minutes of outtakes from the production of A DAY IN THE COUNTRY. The following video essay, written and narrated by Renoir scholar Christopher Faulkner, examines those outtakes.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Ethan Hawke and Jonathan Marc Sherman on BAAL
Description: The following conversation between actor Ethan Hawke and playwright Jonathan Marc Sherman was recorded in New York in November 2017. Hawke and Sherman collaborated on the 2013 stage production “Clive,” an adaptation of Bertolt Brecht’s play “Baal.”

Directed by Krzysztof Kieślowski • 1978 • Poland /  /  /  / Krzysztof Kieślowski made more than twenty documentaries, including the following short. SEVEN WOMEN OF DIFFERENT AGES (1978) subtly portrays a range of ballet dancers, one each day of the week.

Directed by Agnès Varda • 1958 • France /  /  /  / Pregnant with her first child, director Agnès Varda turned her camera to her immediate surroundings capturing day-to-day life along the Rue Mouffetard. Lacking synch sound and incorporating a number of unconventional techniques, this short work displays Varda's freestyle approach to filmmaking and its subject matter.

In this interview, filmmaker Olivier Assayas discusses his love for the films of Sacha Guitry and how pioneering and influential they have been in French cinema. The interview was conducted in New York in October 2016.
Actor Edward Woodward discusses playing Lieutenant Harry “Breaker” Morant in BREAKER MORANT in this 2004 interview.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Mila Parély on THE RULES OF THE GAME
Description: Actor Mila Parély appeared in over forty films, including Jean Renoir’s THE RULES OF THE GAME, Jean Cocteau’s BEAUTY AND THE BEAST, and Max Ophuls’s LE PLAISIR. This 1995 interview with her was produced by Jacques Motte for his documentary HISTOIRE D’UN TOURNAGE EN SOLOGNE, about the making of THE RULES OF THE GAME, and was edited by Criterion.
In the following behind-the-scenes program, director Krzysztof Kieślowski discusses some of the key narrative details in WHITE and the challenges and pleasures of shooting in Poland.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): NIGHT ON EARTH Commentary: New York
Description: Recorded in 2007, this audio commentary features director of photography Frederick Elmes and location sound mixer Drew Kunin.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Chaplin Studios: Creative Freedom by Design
Description: In this piece, visual effects expert Craig Barron takes a look at the set designs created by Charlie Chaplin and his team of artists and technicians—designs whose ingenuity, efficiency, and humor flowed from the unique creative process employed at Chaplin Studios.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Barry Day on IN WHICH WE SERVE
Description: In the following interview, recorded in October 2011, Noël Coward expert Barry Day, author of “Coward on Film: The Cinema of Noël Coward,” discusses IN WHICH WE SERVE.
Critics Imogen Sara Smith and Farran Smith Nehme explore the style and sensibility that Columbia Pictures brought to film noir.
Sofia Coppola discusses growing up in a household of legendary cinephiles, the works that opened her eyes to the possibilities of moviemaking, and the films she wants to share with her own children.
In this 2013 interview, actor Liv Ullmann goes into detail about the making of PERSONA, her connection to the character of Elisabet Vogler, and what she took away from this life-changing experience.

Directed by Gunhild Enger • 2013 • Norway /  / PREMATURE tells the story of Norwegian Martin and his pregnant Spanish girlfriend, Lucia. We follow the pair during their first 15 minutes on Norwegian soil, observing Lucia's first encounter with this new culture and her in‚Äêlaws. The film depicts a car trip full of social tensions, expectations and misunderstandings.

The director of LA LA LAND presents Jean Rouch and Edgar Morin’s revolutionary documentary in Madison, Wisconsin, and examines its pivotal place in the history of nonfiction film with professor Kelley Conway.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Francesco Rosi, Raffaele La Capria, Michel Ciment
Description: In 2006, film critic Michel Ciment interviewed Francesco Rosi and writer Raffaele La Capria about their collaboration and concerns for their native city of Naples.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Isabella Rossellini on THE FLOWERS OF ST. FRANCIS
Description: The following interview with Roberto Rossellini's daughter, actress Isabella Rossellini, was conducted in New York in 2004.
This interview with director Abbas Kiarostami was recorded in Paris in 2012.

Directed by Ali Asgari and Farnoosh Samadi • 2016 • Italy, France /  / Fatma and her mother are Kurdish refugees in Italy. On their visit to the doctor, she has to translate what the doctor tells to her mother but she keeps silent.
This 2015 piece features historian Stephen Miller, author of “Volunteers on the Veld,” discussing the Second Boer War and, in particular, the conflict depicted in BREAKER MORANT.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Brett Halsey on THE ATOMIC SUBMARINE
Edmundo Desnoes on MEMORIES OF UNDERDEVELOPMENT
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2018, Edmundo Desnoes, author of “Inconsolable Memories,” talks about adapting his novel to the screen for MEMORIES OF UNDERDEVELOPMENT.

On September 15, 2001, the Criterion Collection organized a reunion of the cast members of GEORGE WASHINGTON in High Point, North Carolina. Director David Gordon Green conducted the interviews with the cast, in which they discussed the making of the film and life after GEORGE WASHINGTON.
The following interview with LIMELIGHT actress Claire Bloom was conducted in 2015.
In this interview, conducted in 2015, film historian Peter Hames, author of “Czech and Slovak Cinema,” unlocks the surreal charms of VALERIE AND HER WEEK OF WONDERS.
In this interview, conducted in 2016, food stylist Seiko Ogawa talks about her work on Tampopo.

Paul Mason is a criminologist specializing in media representations of prison. He is the editor of “Captured by the Media: Prison Discourse in Popular Culture.” He also directs the Prison Media Monitoring Unit and is a founding member of the group No More Prisons. In this 2007 program, he discusses BRUTE FORCE’s relevance to prison reform.
Directed by David Lowery • 2011 • United States /  / Starring Will Oldham, Myles Brooks /  /  /  / A father tells his son the most epic bedtime story ever.

In 1942, Charlie Chaplin released a sound version of THE GOLD RUSH, effectively abandoning his 1925 silent. In 1993, filmmakers David Gill and Kevin Brownlow reconstructed the original film, for which there were few surviving elements. In this program, Brownlow and Chaplin biographer Jeffrey Vance recount the journey of this comic masterpiece.
Presented here is a “cinema lesson” given by director Wong Kar-wai at the 2001 Cannes Film Festival.

In the following new video essay, location historian and author John Bengston discusses the Los Angeles locations used in the filming of THE KID BROTHER, employing historical research and geographic features to identify specific details.
The following interview with Andrew Rice, author of “The Teeth May Smile but the Heart Does Not Forget: Murder and Memory in Uganda,” was conducted in New York City in August 2017.
These selections from the soundtrack for BEFORE THE RAIN feature the music of the Macedonian band Anastasia.

In this 1992 interview, film and television composer David Raksin, best remembered for his theme music for the film LAURA (1944), recalls the four months he spent with Charlie Chaplin arranging the music for MODERN TIMES. Also presented is a nine-minute piece of the original orchestral track, from the first factory sequence, without sound effects.

Directed by Amy Nicholson • 2015 • United States /  / Let us reflect on the brief existence of Pickle the fish. Although he could not swim, he was lovingly cared for by a couple that kept him propped up in a sponge. Along with an obese chicken, a cat with a heart condition, and a paraplegic possum, his life is a celebration of man's eternal capacity to care for all creatures. He will be dearly missed.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Eddie Axberg on HERE IS YOUR LIFE
Description: The following interview with actor Eddie Axberg was conducted in Stockholm in March 2015.
Made in 2014 by White Dolphin Films, this documentary provides a look at ODD MAN OUT through archival material and interviews with filmmakers, director Carol Reed’s collaborators, and critics.

Directed by Hu Wei • 2013 • China /  /  /  / A young photographer and his assistant take pictures of Tibetan nomads. Against diverse and more or less exotic backgrounds, families appear to the photographer. Through these shots, the photographer will weave unique links with each of the various villagers.

In this interview, shot in London in 2010, novelist and film critic Kim Newman discusses how the groundbreaking DIABOLIQUE has influenced countless horror films, including Alfred Hitchcock’s PSYCHO. Newman’s books include “The Hound of the d’Urbervilles: The Crime-Book of Professor Moriarty” and “Nightmare Movies: Forty Years of Fear.”

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Mira Nair on THE MUSIC ROOM
Description: In this interview, recorded in 2011, filmmaker Mira Nair (SALAAM BOMBAY!, MONSOON WEDDING) discusses her admiration for Satyajit Ray and THE MUSIC ROOM.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Agnès Varda on LA POINTE COURTE
Description: This 2007 interview was shot at director Agnès Varda’s home office on the rue Daguerre in Paris.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Rémi Fournier Lanzoni on IL SORPASSO
Description: Italy’s highest-grossing film of 1962, IL SORPASSO is among the most beloved movies of the golden age of commedia all’italiana, which lasted from the late 1950s to the 1970s. In this 2014 interview, scholar Rémi Fournier Lanzoni discussed the film’s resonance with Italian audiences, its social commentary, and how it embodies Dino Risi’s style.
In this short documentary from 2007, Romanian audience members are asked for their responses after viewing 4 MONTHS, 3 WEEKS AND 2 DAYS.

On February 12, 1973, right after L'ENFANCE NUE first aired on French television, Maurice Pialat was interviewed by Michel Martens for an episode of the program “Champ contre-champ,” directed by Maurice Frydland. In these excerpts, Pialat discusses L'ENFANCE NUE's subject matter, its commercial failure, and his intentions as a filmmaker.

Jean-Pierre Gorin and Jean-Luc Godard made seven films together as the Dziga-Vertov Group, including 1972’s TOUT VA BIEN. In this interview, Gorin discusses Godard's deepening narrative, historical, and cultural experimentation in MASCULIN FÉMININ. The Criterion Collection interviewed Gorin in New York, in March of 2005.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Jean Renoir parle de son art: Part 2
Description: In the following 1961 interview, Jean Renoir discusses with French New Wave director Jacques Rivette his design of the “seventh art” and art in general, demolishing certain generally accepted ideas, and evoking some memories from his own career.
In the following 2015 piece, director Takashi Murakami’s special effects crew and clay model makers bring to life the F.R.I.E.N.D.S. of JELLYFISH EYES.
