This piece features a 2015 interview with filmmaker Aaron Brookner, BURROUGHS: THE MOVIE director Howard Brookner’s nephew.

Chosen at the last moment to play Gradisca in director Federico Fellini’s AMARCORD, Magali Noël threw herself into the role with typical verve and charm. She also appeared in Fellini’s LA DOLCE VITA and SATYRICON, in addition to such films as RIFIFI and Z.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Mutations of Memory: Editing in HIROSHIMA MON AMOUR
Description: Professor David Bordwell traces the ways in which director Alain Resnais and screenwriter Marguerite Duras retooled cinematic language to evoke the texture of memory in their 1959 masterpiece.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Kumar Shahani on A RIVER CALLED TITAS
Description: In this 2013 interview, filmmaker Kumar Shahani (KHAYAL GATHA), a former student of Ritwik Ghatak’s, shares his appreciation for Ghatak’s 1973 film A RIVER CALLED TITAS.
In this interview, conducted in 2015, director Bruce Beresford recounts his experiences making MISTER JOHNSON.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): The Making of ANTICHRIST: Visual Style
Description: Made in 2010 by Zentropa’s DVD production company, Electric Parc.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): President Nixon Resigns the Office of the Presidency
Description: The following was broadcast live nationwide on August 8, 1974.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Joshua Oppenheimer on NIGHT AND FOG
Description: This interview with filmmaker Joshua Oppenheimer was conducted in Copenhagen in April 2016.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Tony Rayns on PIGS AND BATTLESHIPS
Description: This interview with film critic Tony Rayns was conducted in December 2008.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Casper Tybjerg on MASTER OF THE HOUSE
Description: In this interview, produced in 2014, Danish film historian Casper Tybjerg discusses how MASTER OF THE HOUSE went from being a popular stage play to a film, one that was a major stepping-stone in director Carl Theodor Dreyer’s career.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): More Than a Soundtrack: The Valerie Project
Description: In this piece, produced in 2015, Joseph A. Gervasi and Greg Weeks, cofounders of the Philadelphia-based psych-folk ensemble the Valerie Project, discuss VALERIE AND HER WEEK OF WONDERS and how it inspired them to create a unique alternate score.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Suzanne Schiffman on SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER
Description: This rare interview with Suzanne Schiffman, François Truffaut’s closest collaborator, was conducted in April 1986, in Paris. The interview was originally intended for Rainer Gansera’s documentary WORKING WITH TRUFFAUT. The Criterion Collection gained access to the complete interview and edited a version exclusively for this DVD edition.

Adrian Utley, of the band Portishead, and Goldfrapp’s Will Gregory composed their score for THE PASSION OF JOAN OF ARC in 2010. This conversation between the two was filmed at Utley’s home in Bristol, England, in 2017.

In this 1981 interview with Ingmar Bergman, excerpted from Gösta Werner’s feature documentary VICTOR SJÖSTRÖM: A PORTRAIT, the filmmaker discusses his deep admiration for Sjöström—director of THE PHANTOM CARRIAGE—as well as the influence he had on his own career and their work together on WILD STRAWBERRIES.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Musicians of THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN
Description: In this 2010 video portrait, the musicians from THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN discuss their integral role in the film.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Peter Bogdanovich and Noah Baumbach on FRANCES HA
Description: The following conversation between filmmaker Peter Bogdanovich and Noah Baumbach was recorded in New York City in June 2013.

EVERYDAY REALITIES: TONY RAYNS ON NEW TAIWAN CINEMA AND EDWARD YANG features the noted Asian-cinema critic discussing the cinematic movement, its key players and characteristics, and the qualities that distinguish Edward Yang and his work from his contemporaries.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Masaki Kobayashi and Masahiro Shinoda on KWAIDAN
Description: This conversation between director Masaki Kobayashi and filmmaker Masahiro Shinoda about the making of KWAIDAN was shot in 1993 for the Directors Guild of Japan.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Ingmar Bergman on SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE
Description: In this 1986 interview for Swedish television, Ingmar Bergman reflects on the making of SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE, discussing the characters he created and the strong response they elicited from their audience.

Robert Christides was employed as set decorator on both LE PLAISIR and LOLA MONTES. He continued to work as a set decorator, art director, and production designer in a career that spanned thirty years. This 1989 interview was conducted in Paris by Martina Muller.

In this interview excerpt, playwright Shelagh Delaney discusses growing up in Salford, England, and writing her hit play “A Taste of Honey” at the age of eighteen. The interview aired in 1960 on the television series “Close-Up.”
This short documentary from 2015 discusses the ongoing work by the Wim Wenders Foundation to restore the filmmaker’s early output.
In this program, shot in 1993, during the filming of BEFORE THE RAIN, cast and crew share their thoughts about working together in Macedonia and the challenges they faced.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Antoine Bourseiller on 2 OR 3 THINGS I KNOW ABOUT HER
Description: Theater director, actor, and author Antoine Bourseiller was a close friend of both Jean-Luc Godard and Anna Karina in the sixties (his children play Marina Vlady’s children in 2 OR 3 THINGS I KNOW ABOUT HER). In this interview, he recounts the “warlike friendship” he shared with Godard, until it was disrupted by the director’s turn to Maoism.
In 1975 the Martha Graham Dance Company filmed a technique demonstration in three parts. Presented here are excerpts from that film, which Graham narrates.

This short documentary, shot at the time of RED’s world premiere at the Cannes Film Festival, includes interviews with director Krzysztof Kieślowski and actors Irène Jacob and Jean-Louis Trintignant, as well as footage of Kieślowski announcing his retirement from filmmaking.

The following interview with Chantal Goya was recorded in Paris, in May 2005. In it, she looks back on her career as a singer and on the experience of working with Jean-Luc Godard on MASCULIN FÉMININ.
This documentary, made in 2002, features interviews with filmmakers Allison Anders, Kurt Voss, and Dean Lent, and actors Chris D. and John Doe.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Metin Erksan and Fatih Akin on DRY SUMMER
Description: This 2013 program features excerpts from a 2008 interview with the late director Metin Erksan and a new interview with filmmaker Fatih Akin (HEAD-ON), both of whom reflect on Erksan's 1964 film.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Soumitra Chatterjee and Sharmila Tagore on APUR SANSAR
Description: In the following program, produced in 2015, Soumitra Chatterjee and Sharmila Tagore talk about what it was like acting for director Satyajit Ray and their experiences making APUR SANSAR, the debut film for each of them.

Before working with director Nicolas Roeg, INSIGNIFICANCE editor Tony Lawson had collaborated with such acclaimed filmmakers as Sam Peckinpah (on STRAW DOGS) and Stanley Kubrick (on BARRY LYNDON). The following interview with Lawson was conducted exclusively in London in December 2010.

In this 2010 visual essay, John Bengtson, author of “Silent Traces: Discovering Early Hollywood Through the Films of Charlie Chaplin,” tours the locations used in MODERN TIMES through photographs, vintage maps, and film clips, revealing what Chaplin’s camera captured of the backdrop to the silent era and how things have changed.

Directed by Luca Tóth • 2016 • Czech Republic /  / In the land of Superbia strict rules devide the societies of women and men, maintained also physically by the Milk River originating from the Cow God. Different customs and manners estrange the sexes far apart, the strong and sturdy women on one side and the decent and delicate men on the other. The story follows three main characters. A man and a woman find their ways to each other against all odds. Their actions become the catalyst of change within the societies, sparking a cultural revolution. The third and most conflicted character is a nemesis female character who does not want or does not know how to adapt to a coming, unknown new era.

Bronja Clair met her future husband in 1924, at the premiere of his film ENTR’ACTE, and became an active participant with him in the French art world. She remembers René Clair and his art in this 1998 interview.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Magazine: An Homage to Jacques Tati
Description: In this 1982 episode of the French television show “Magazine,” artist and set designer Jacques Lagrange pays tribute to his friend Jacques Tati through anecdotes about his collaboration with the filmmaker.
In this 2013 interview, filmmaker Bong Joon-ho (THE HOST) shares his appreciation for Kim Ki-young’s 1960 film THE HOUSEMAID.
This interview with director Olivier Assayas was conducted in New York in March 2018.

Directed by Franck Dion • 2012 • Canada /  / This animated short about social conformity tells the story of Edmond - a very 'different' sort of guy. When his co-workers jokingly crown him with a pair of donkey ears, Edmond suddenly discovers his true identity. And while he enjoys his newfound self, the ears create an ever-widening gap between himself and others.

In this interview program from 2003, film critic Geoff Andrew, filmmaker Agnieszka Holland, cinematographer Sławomir Idziak, film studies professor Annette Insdorf, and actor Irène Jacob examine director Krzysztof Kieślowski’s formative years and the political and social circumstances that shaped his direction and philosophical choices in cinema.
In this interview shot in 2017, actor Sherwan Haji discusses his move to Finland, working with director Aki Kaurismäki, and the ongoing plight of Syrian refugees.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Tony Richardson on A TASTE OF HONEY
Description: This audio interview with screenwriter and director Tony Richardson is presented with film clips and behind-the-scenes images. The interview, conducted by critic Gideon Bachmann at the 1962 Cannes Film Festival, covers the state of British cinema, Richardson’s filmmaking methods, and what drew him to adapt “A Taste of Honey” for the screen.

In 2006 Agnès Varda gathered four intellectuals from various professions and backgrounds—freelance writer-journalist Michèle Manceaux, producer and distributor Gérard Vaugeois, journalist and critic Frédéric Bonnaud, and Fadela Amara, president of the organization Ni putes ni soumises, which seeks to help women of Arab and North African descent assert their rights—to discuss their thoughts on LE BONHEUR as a film and happiness as a concept.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Tokuzo Tanaka on SANSHO THE BAILIFF
Description: Tokuzo Tanaka was first assistant director on SANSHO THE BAILIFF, and in this 2007 interview, he offers a complex portrait of Kenji Mizoguchi, outlines the methods employed by the filmmaking team, and remembers the director’s surprising feelings about the film.

Harold Lloyd broke ground for his elaborate Los Angeles estate, Greenacres, during the filming of THE KID BROTHER. Presented here is a 2005 featurette in which Suzanne Lloyd provides a tour of the estate.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): MR. ARKADIN Outtakes and Rushes: Orson Welles Acting
Description: Found in the archives of the Cinémathèque municipale de Luxembourg, the footage shown here represents outtakes, work prints, and rushes Orson Welles used to construct MR. ARKADIN, at least as far as he was able. It is extremely rare, and some of the only material in existence showing Welles in the act of directing.
Directed by Sam Kuhn • 2017 • United States, Canada /  / A tale of magic and mutation half remembered by a teen poet whose beloved has mysteriously disappeared.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Jean Renoir: A Passage Through India
Description: This video essay by film writer Paul Ryan on Jean Renoir’s approach to filming Rumer Godden’s novel “The River” features rare behind-the-scenes stills and location-scouting footage.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Willy Kurant on THE IMMORTAL STORY
Description: Director of photography Willy Kurant discusses shooting THE IMMORTAL STORY for Orson Welles, in this July 2004 interview.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Arnošt Lustig Through the Eyes of Jan Němec
Description: In this fourteen-minute film from 1993, director Jan Němec pays tribute to author Arnošt Lustig, whose work he adapted for Loaf of Bread and DIAMONDS OF THE NIGHT.
Directed by Katarzyna Gondek • 2017 • Poland, Belgium, Croatia /  / DEER BOY is a story about a hunter's son, who was born with antlers, and about how each man kills the thing he loves.

Directed by Chloë Sevigny • 2016 • United States /  / Adapted from Paul Bowles' short story of the same name, KITTY displays Chloë Sevigny's inventive and singular aesthetic in a story about a little girl who dreams of becoming a kitten and finds herself transformed into one.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Barry Day on THIS HAPPY BREED
Description: In the following interview, recorded in October 2011, Noël Coward expert Barry Day, author of “Coward on Film: The Cinema of Noël Coward,” discusses THIS HAPPY BREED.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Peter Cowie on SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE
Description: SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE was originally filmed as a six-part television series and then edited by Ingmar Bergman into a feature film. In this program, filmed in 2004, renowned Bergman expert Peter Cowie talks about the making of the two versions and the choices made by the director in the editing process.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Peter Cowie on SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE
Description: SCENES FROM A MARRIAGE was originally filmed as a six-part television series and then edited by Ingmar Bergman into a feature film. In this program, filmed in 2004, renowned Bergman expert Peter Cowie talks about the making of the two versions and the choices made by the director in the editing process.
In this short documentary from 2005, Louis Malle’s assistant director, Philippe Collin, gives us a tour of ZAZIE DANS LE MÉTRO’s Paris locations while relating anecdotes about the film’s production.

Sony Pictures Classics cofounders Michael Barker, Tom Bernard, and Marcie Bloom first collaborated with director Pedro Almodóvar at Orion Classics in 1988, on the hit WOMEN ON THE VERGE OF A NERVOUS BREAKDOWN. In this interview, conducted in April 2014, Barker reflects on his many years of working with the director.
Directed by Sam Taylor-Johnson • 2008 • United Kingdom /  / Two teenagers are drawn together by the Buzzcocks' single Love You More during the summer of 1978.

In this 2009 video piece, actors Andréa Ferréol, Paulette Dubost, and Sabine Haudepin, along with actor and second assistant director Alain Tasma, recall the joys and challenges of working on THE LAST METRO.

Directed by Krzysztof Kieślowski • 1980 • Poland /  /  /  / Krzysztof Kieślowski made more than twenty documentaries, including the following short. In TALKING HEADS, Kieślowski poses the questions “What year were you born?” “Who are you?” and “What do you most wish for?” to forty different people, ranging from an infant to a one-hundred-year-old woman.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Bengt Forslund on HERE IS YOUR LIFE
Description: Bengt Forslund, who produced and cowrote HERE IS YOUR LIFE, was a major force in Swedish filmmaking in the 1960s. In this interview, conducted in Stockholm in March 2015, Forslund describes the transformation of his nation’s cinema during that decade.

Directed by Satsuki Okawa • 2011 • Japan, United States /  / Following the death of his hoarder mother, a young man eagerly looks forward to cleaning out her junk-strewn home—but first he’ll have to contend with his sister, who is intent on preserving the house just as it is—in this tender look at grief and letting go.

In this visual essay, Peter Cowie, one of the world’s leading experts on Ingmar Bergman, discusses many of the themes in THE MAGICIAN and places them within the context of the director’s body of work.
In this introduction to LA HAINE from 2006, acclaimed actor and filmmaker Jodie Foster discusses her passion for the film and the reasons she championed and presented it in the United States.
The following interview with LIMELIGHT actor Norman Lloyd was conducted 2012.

Directed by Niki Lindroth von Bahr • 2017 • Sweden /  / A dark musical enacted in a modern marketplace, situated next to a large freeway. The employees of the various commercial venues, portrayed as animals, deal with boredom and existential anxiety by performing cheerful musical turns. The apocalypse is a tempting liberator.

In 2016, director Kirsten Johnson traveled with Cameraperson to two film festival that had unique connections to the content of her documentary. Both screenings were followed by in-depth conversations with Johnson. An edited program from one of those live events is presented here.

In these interviews, recorded in Bologna, Italy; Monterey; and New York City in 2017, director D.A. Pennebaker recalls his experiences making MONTEREY POP fifty years earlier, and reminisces about a few of the people who became friends and some of the performances that became legendary.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Arturo Ripstein on THE EXTERMINATING ANGEL
Description: Growing up in Mexico City as the son of a film producer, Arturo Ripstein met numerous directors, but it wasn’t until he encountered the work of Luis Buñuel that he decided to embark on a career in cinema himself. In this 2006 interview, Ripstein discusses having access to the set of THE EXTERMINATING ANGEL and observing Buñuel at work.
Produced by the British Ministry of Information in 1943, this film is a tribute to newsreel and service film unit cameramen and features some of the most dramatic footage shot during the war.
This introduction to PICKPOCKET by writer-director Paul Schrader was recorded in 2004. Please note: the introduction contains remarks about the ending of the film.

Directed by Pierre Etaix • 1966 • France /  / This short was originally one of the sequences of As Long as You're Healthy, in its 1965 version. In 1971, Pierre Étaix re-edited it to a short feature: Feeling good. In 2010, it was presented in the general reissue of his films.

In this 2011 introduction, film preservationist and historian Serge Bromberg, director of HENRI-GEORGES CLOUZOT’S ”INFERNO,” a 2009 documentary about Clouzot’s legendary uncompleted film, talks about how the filmmaker put his unique visual stamp on DIABOLIQUE.
Charlie Rose interview with David Gordon Green from 2001

In 1988, Jean Oser, the editor of KAMERADSCHAFT, recorded these audio responses to questions sent to him by film scholar Hermann Barth. Intercut with Oser’s responses are scenes from the rare French cut of the film.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Hafsia Herzi on THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN
Description: In this 2010 interview, actress Hafsia Herzi, who plays Rym, discusses the making of THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): LYDIA and the Power of Flashbacks
Description: Professor David Bordwell illuminates how Julien Duvivier’s haunting, exquisitely bittersweet romantic drama deploys intricate, subjective flashback sequences to enhance its sublime emotional impact.

In these short excerpts from the November 26, 1978, episode of “Ciné regards,” critic Michel Ciment and writer Georges Perec look at the ways Yasujiro Ozu’s filmmaking style changed over the course of his career. They focus in particular on his AN AUTUMN AFTERNOON (a.k.a. THE TASTE OF SAKE).

Directed by Juho Kuosmanen  • 2017 • Finland /  /  /  / The first Finnish film was made in 1907, but sadly lost forever. So to mark the 100th anniversary year of the Finnish independence, film has now been remade by Juho Kuosmanen (THE HAPPIEST DAY IN THE LIFE OF OLLI MÄKI) following several silent film traditions: shot on B&W 16 mm film and performed with live music and a live foley artist. In the film two siblings inherit all the essentials for a good life: moonshine equipment and a pig. As they embark on their journey, business is good until a card shark arrives.
Pianist René Urtreger, the only musician from the soundtrack session for ELEVATOR TO THE GALLOWS still living, was interviewed in 2005 for the film’s French DVD release.

The following rare audio recording, provided by the Library of Congress, is a promotional radio spot for the 1941 theatrical release of THAT HAMILTON WOMAN. It features excerpts from the film and commentary from the set.
In this excerpt from a 1989 episode of the German television show “Das Sonntagsgespräch” (Sunday Talk), director Bernhard Wicki discusses the making of THE BRIDGE.
The following silent movie was shot and edited on Super 8 by filmmaker Tom Jarmusch, director Jim Jarmusch’s brother, during the filming of STRANGER THAN PARADISE.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Beatrice Welles on CHIMES AT MIDNIGHT
Description: Beatrice Welles was nine years old when her father, Orson Welles, made CHIMES AT MIDNIGHT. In this January 2016 interview, she recalls the atmosphere on set and her reluctance to play Falstaff’s young page.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Joyce Van Patten and Julian Schlossberg on MIKEY AND NICKY
Description: This program, featuring new interviews with actor Joyce Van Patten and distributor Julian Schlossberg, explores director Elaine May's approach to the making of MIKEY AND NICKY—from working with actors to the look of the film.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Sophia Loren on A SPECIAL DAY
Description: This interview with actor Sophia Loren was conducted in Geneva in June 2015. In it, she recalls working with director Ettore Scola on A SPECIAL DAY, her fears about playing Antonietta, and the challenges of shooting the love scene.
This interview with film enthusiast and historian Pierre Rissient was produced in 2017.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): A Long Time on the Little Road
Description: In 1957, director Satyajit Ray wrote an article for the British magazine “Sight & Sound” about the making of PATHER PANCHALI. Shortly thereafter, critic Gideon Bachmann recorded Ray reading his account aloud. That audio recording is presented here.
This 2007 piece features CORRIDORS OF BLOOD director Robert Day and actor Francis Matthews.
Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1933 • France /  / Jean Painlevé's classic underwater short THE SEA HORSE uses dreamlike imagery to detail the lives of the titular upright-swimming creatures.
Director Ingmar Bergman talks about SHAME in this fifteen-minute excerpt from an interview recorded for the Swedish television program Forum and originally broadcast on September 19, 1968.

The following interview with Barbet Schroeder was recorded at his home in New York City in 2002. Schroeder set up his own production company in 1964 and produced such films as Eric Rohmer’s MY NIGHT AT MAUD’S. Since 1969, he has had a distinguished career as a director of both documentaries and narrative films, including GENERAL IDI AMIN DADA, BARFLY, and REVERSAL OF FORTUNE.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK: Cleve Jones Interview
Description: During preproduction on THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK, director Robert Epstein recorded draft interviews with more than forty people before deciding on the eight subjects seen in the film. Presented here is an excerpt from an interview with gay rights activist Cleve Jones, which was not included in the film.
Directed by Qiu Yang • 2017 • China /  / In a nameless Chinese city, a mother with her daughter missing, refuses to go gentle into this good night.

Harold Nebenzal, son of Seymour Nebenzal, sat down with Criterion in 2004 to discuss his father’s pioneering independent company, Nero Films, producer of such titles as PANDORA’S BOX, M, THE THREEPENNY OPERA, and THE TESTAMENT OF DR. MABUSE. Harold worked on his father’s 1951 remake of M and on CABARET, and is the author of the novel “Café Berlin.”

In 1958, director Satyajit Ray attended the Robert Flaherty Film Seminar, on the occasion of the U.S. release of PATHER PANCHALI. Ray had by then completed APARAJITO and THE PHILOSOPHER’S STONE, and THE MUSIC ROOM would soon premiere. Presented here are audio excerpts of a conversation Ray had with film critic Gideon Bachmann during the seminar.
Set designer Rashit Safiullin discusses working on STALKER in this interview from 2000.
This interview with HARAKIRI star Tatsuya Nakadai was conducted in Tokyo in 2005. In it, the Japanese screen legend discusses his career and his performance in the film.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK: Amber Hollibaugh Interview
Description: During preproduction on THE TIMES OF HARVEY MILK, director Robert Epstein recorded draft interviews with more than forty people before deciding on the eight subjects seen in the film. Presented here are excerpts from an interview with writer and activist Amber Hollibaugh, which was not included in the film.

Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1960 • France /  / Through a combination of underwater, time-lapse, and microscopic photography, Jean Painlevé creates a beautiful study of the reproduction cycle of jellyfish.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Johanna ter Steege on THE VANISHING
Description: Johanna ter Steege made her film debut as Saskia in THE VANISHING, which earned her the European Film Award for best supporting actress. In this interview, conducted in Amsterdam in 2014, she recalls the extensive backstory she created for her character, working with director George Sluizer, and how the experience shaped her approach to acting.

Working with a subject as intensely studied as the French Revolution, and with a director who was not French, scriptwriter Jean-Claude Carrière knew he was walking into sensitive territory with DANTON. In this interview recorded in 2009 Carrière describes how he navigated that intellectual mine field.
Directed by Josh Safdie • 2006 • United States /  / Two siblings accidentally pick up a hitchhiker on their way to the zoo.

Silvia Pinal acted in dozens of films in Mexico before traveling to Spain to work with Luis Buñuel on VIRIDIANA. One of the leading figures in Mexico’s entertainment industry, she has acted, produced, and raised a family of entertainers—not to mention served a term in the Mexican legislature. The following interview was conducted in January 2006.
This interview with actor Isabelle Huppert was recorded in 2010.

Directed by Stuart Cooper • 1969 • United Kingdom /  / In 1969, Stuart Cooper made this short film about the work of Spanish artist Juan Genovés, whose paintings depict the horror of oppression and brutality. It won prizes at the Berlin, Moscow, and Venice film festivals. It also caught the attention of James Quinn of the Imperial War Museum, which ultimately led to Cooper’s directing OVERLORD.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Geoff Brown on GREEN FOR DANGER
Description: Film scholar Geoff Brown has written numerous books on British cinema, including “Launder and Gilliat” and “Michael Balcon: The Pursuit of British Cinema.” The following interview was recorded in 2005.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): The Love Life of the Octopus
Description: Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1967 • France /  / The mating rituals and reproductive cycle of the octopus are the subject of this short documentary by Jean Painlevé.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): LES ENFANTS TERRIBLES: About the Film
Description: In this short 2007 video, producer Carole Weisweiller, actor Jacques Bernard, and assistant director Claude Pinoteau discuss the making of LES ENFANTS TERRIBLES.
Directed by Ivan Passer • 1968 • Czechoslovakia /  / Patrons of a bar interact on a summer Sunday afternoon.
This piece features actor Kierston Wareing, who was interviewed in London in the fall of 2010.
In this 2010 video piece, acclaimed filmmaker and John Ford biographer Peter Bogdanovich offers his thoughts on STAGECOACH.
Actor Norman Eshley’s appearance in THE IMMORTAL STORY came very early in his long television career. In this new interview, shot in May 2016, he discusses playing the sailor in Orson Welles’s film.

Award-winning filmmaker Ettore Scola began his career as a screenwriter, working with Dino Risi on a number of his films, including IL SORPASSO. In this November 2013 interview, Scola talks about Italian comedy filmmaking in the sixties, writing the character of Bruno, and the necessity of the film’s tragic ending.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Grigori Chukhrai and Actors on BALLAD OF A SOLDIER
Description: This interview with director/co-screenwriter Grigori Chukhrai and actors Vladimir Ivashov and Zhanna Prokhorenko was conducted by Gideon Bachmann for “Film Art” on radio station WBAI at the Four Seasons restaurant in New York, after a special preview screening of BALLAD OF A SOLDIER.

Directed by Sophie Tatischeff • 1978 • France /  / Directed by Jacques Tati's daughter Sophie Tatischeff, Dégustation maison is a thirteen-minute comic short shot in a café in Sainte-Sévère-sur-Indre, the same town where Tati's Jour de fěte was filmed. It won the Cesar Award for best short fiction film in 1978.
This short video piece, shot during the making of INSIGNIFICANCE, features interviews with actors Gary Busey, Tony Curtis, and Theresa Russell, among others.
This interview with filmmaker Walter Salles, founder of the Mário Peixoto Archives, was produced in 2017.

The following interview with director Seijun Suzuki was recorded during a retrospective of his work by the Japan Foundation and Los Angeles Filmforum at the Nuart Theatre in Los Angeles in March 1997.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Faye Ginsburg on CHRONICLE OF A SUMMER
Description: In this October 2012 interview, anthropology professor Faye Ginsburg discusses CHRONICLE OF A SUMMER in the context of Jean Rouch’s career.
Directed by Yasujiro Ozu • 1929 • Japan /  / A kidnapped boy proves to be more than his abductor can handle.

The director of such classics as PALE FLOWER (1964), SAMURAI SPY (1965), and DOUBLE SUICIDE (1969), Masahiro Shinoda considers Kenji Mizoguchi’s UGETSU one of cinema’s crowning achievements. This interview with Shinoda took place in Tokyo in May 2005.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Joshua Oppenheimer on THE THIN BLUE LINE
Description: The following interview with filmmaker Joshua Oppenheimer about THE THIN BLUE LINE was conducted in December 2014.

Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1937 • France /  / On assignment for the mathematics department of le Palais de la Découverte, Jean Painlevé shot this film to be presented at the Paris museum's 1937 international exhibition. THE STRUGGLE FOR SURVIVAL explores population rise and decline.

The following extended scene features a longer version of an interview with actors Sigourney Weaver, Isabella Rossellini, and Liv Ullmann at the Shubert Theatre in New York that appears in INGRID BERGMAN: IN HER OWN WORDS.

Directed by Alfred J. Goulding • 1919 • United States /  / This 1919 one-reeler stars Harold Lloyd as one of Bebe Daniels' many suitors, who, after a series of mishaps, ends up running in a local marathon. It is presented here with a new score composed and performed by Gabriel Thibaudeau.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Miloš Forman on THE FIREMEN’S BALL
Description: This interview with director Miloš Forman was conducted in New York City in the spring of 2001.
In this video interview, conducted in 2011, renowned Japanese-film critic Tadao Sato looks at GODZILLA in terms of Japanese culture.

Directed by Christopher Radcliff and Lauren Wolkstein • 2011 • United States /  / Two travelers - a man and a boy - whose car has broken down stumble upon a small roadside motel, where a girl offer to help them. At first, all seems normal, but an unseen tension begins to mount between the three of them, leading to a startling discovery. Christopher Radcliff and Lauren Wolkstein's multi-award winning short THE STRANGE ONES strips away the ordinary to offer a brief glimpse of a complicated, dangerous and secret world lurking underneath.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): The Revolutionary Subjectivity of MEMORIES OF UNDERDEVELOPMENT
Description: The first Cuban film to garner international attention in the years following the nation’s 1959 revolution, Tomás Gutiérrez Alea’s MEMORIES OF UNDERDEVELOPMENT remains one of the most important works of the influential Third Cinema movement that emerged in the developing world as a response to neocolonialist modes of filmmaking. In this episode of Observations on Film Art, Professor Jeff Smith explores the film’s complex depiction of its notably unsympathetic central character—a misanthropic bourgeois intellectual whose moral apathy has rendered him a relic of a bygone era—and how Alea uses a variety of innovative stylistic techniques to evoke his subjectivity. In doing so, Smith illuminates how this landmark of Cuban cinema challenged audiences to evaluate their own commitment to the revolution.

Directed by Niki Lindroth von Bahr • 2014 • Sweden /  / Six characters meet in a bath house. The pedant bath house manager, a couple with a strange way of communicating and a gang with shady intentions. Something goes wrong.
When Ingmar Bergman cast Liv Ullmann in PERSONA, he initiated a remarkable creative partnership that would last well beyond the passionate, years-long affair that also blossomed between them.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Print: In Memory of Abbas Kiarostami
Description: In 2018, Salma Monshizadeh, Abbas Kiarostami’s former longtime assistant, assembled this short documentary from footage of the making of 24 Frames.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Games of Vision in STREET OF SHAME

Description: In 2005 the Sundance Film Festival inducted HARLAN COUNTY USA into the Sundance Collection. The following panel discussion features producer-director Barbara Kopple, cinematographer Hart Perry, editor Nancy Baker, musician Hazel Dickens, and film critic Roger Ebert. Kopple also invited striking Utah coal miners to talk about their struggles.
Olivier Assayas sings the praises of an underrated French filmmaker.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Patti Smith on Bob Dylan and DONT LOOK BACK
Description: In this interview, conducted in August 2015, musician Patti Smith discusses the role Bob Dylan and DONT LOOK BACK have played in her life, as well as tour manager Bob Neuwirth, who served as a mentor early in her career.
Directed by Sofia Coppola • 1998 • United States /  /  /  / Sofia Coppola made the following 16 mm short film in 1998, the same year she began production on THE VIRGIN SUICIDES.

Directed by Guy Maddin • 2009 • Canada /  / This short Guy Maddin film tells the story of inventor Nihad Ademi, who harnesses the power of the aurora borealis in Winnipeg in 1939. Ademi uses this power to broadcast images of Canada to its own citizens from coast to coast, but in the process angers he the government.
Directed by Alain Resnais • 1959 • France /  / Poetic and aesthetic visit of a large polystyrene factory.

The original dance “Appalachian Spring,” which premiered at the Library of Congress on October 30, 1944, was part of the Graham company repertoire for many years before Nathan Kroll documented it. Here dance Critic Deborah Jowitt compares excerpts of an earlier filmed performance of the dance, featuring Martha Graham, Eric Hawkins, and Merce Cunninghams, with the 1958 film.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Colin MacCabe on THE LONG DAY CLOSES
Description: In this interview, conducted in New York in 2013, film critic and professor Colin MacCabe describes his former role as the head of the BFI Production Board, which funded director Terence Davies’s early films Death and Transfiguration and Distant Voices, Still Lives. As an executive producer of The Long Day Closes, MacCabe also discusses the financial obstacles encountered by Davies’s films and the unique process of actualizing one of his scripts.
Actor-director Toni Servillo, who plays the character Franco in GOMORRAH, is from the region in Italy where the film is set. He was interviewed in July 2009 in Rome.

A longtime fan of American jazz vocalist Dave Lambert, D. A. Pennebaker jumped at the chance to film him auditioning a new group of singers at RCA in 1964. The resulting film helped the director understand his artistic mission—as he put it, “Recording people and music as a kind of popular history that might not otherwise exist.”
Filmmaker Martin Scorsese recorded the following introduction to THE LIFE AND DEATH OF COLONEL BLIMP in 2012. The piece was edited by Thelma Schoonmaker Powell.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Francesco Rosi on THE MOMENT OF TRUTH
Description: In this interview, recorded in Italy in 2004, director Francesco Rosi discusses THE MOMENT OF TRUTH.
This 1962 episode of the French television show “Cinépanorama” features an interview with actor Jeanne Moreau on the set of BAY OF ANGELS.
This episode of “The Dick Cavett Show” features a guest appearance by director Barbara Loden promoting WANDA. It airead March 4, 1971.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Dissolves in THE LONG DAY CLOSES
Description: Professor Kristin Thompson explores the ways in which dissolves allow Terence Davies to mimic the fluidity and emotional texture of memory in his elegiac coming-of-age film.

Directed by Rosie Reed Hillman • 2014 • United Kingdom /  / Morag is 86. She lives alone at the end of a track looking out to sea on her croft on the Isle of Harris, Outer Hebrides, with her three cats and twelve sheep. Morag was born in this house and has lived here her whole life, following five generations of the family who came before her. CAILLEACH is a portrait of Morag and her simple and peaceful life as she contemplates her next chapter, shares her unique sense of independence and the connection she has to her wild island home.

Presented here is a 2009 interview with Brad Dourif, who has acted in over one hundred feature films, including LORD OF THE RINGS: THE TWO TOWERS, BLUE VELVET, and MISSISSIPPI BURNING. He was nominated for an Academy Award for his portrayal of Billy Bibbit in ONE FLEW OVER THE CUCKOO’S NEST.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Hsu Feng on A TOUCH OF ZEN
Description: Conducted in 2016, this interview features actor Hsu Feng discussing her iconic role as Yang Hui-zhen in A TOUCH OF ZEN.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Masaki Kobayashi on THE HUMAN CONDITION
Description: In this 1993 video interview, filmed for the Directors Guild of Japan at Tokyo’s Haiyuza Theatre, director Masaki Kobayashi talks to fellow filmmaker and longtime Kobayashi admirer Masahiro Shinoda (DOUBLE SUICIDE) about THE HUMAN CONDITION.

Directed by Charles Burnett • 1973 • United States /  /  /  / A young boy keeps a horse company during its last moments of life in Charels Burnett’s spare, lyrical student film, which poignantly contrasts the callousness of adults with the empathy of children. /  /  /  / Limited engagement ends September 30
Directed by Pierre Etaix and Jean-Claude Carrière • 1962 • France /  / A young woman waits and waits for her delayed husband to celebrate their wedding anniversary.

Directed by Elnura Osmonalieva • 2015 • Kyrgyzstan /  / Young Seide lives in a secluded mountain village in the heart of Kyrgyzstan. She loves her freedom to ride her horse, the closest soul she has, and enjoys playing with the village boys. When she is faced with the prospect of an arranged marriage, her family decides to honour the tradition and kill Seide's horse for the wedding celebration. Upset and feeling voiceless, Seide tries to understand her family's decision but cannot let her horse be killed. Unfortunately, the horse, like herself, has no way of escape. Alone and broken hearted Seide stays in her old but forever changed world.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Scenes from the Making of THE KING OF KINGS
Description: The DeMille Studios produced many reels of behind-the-scenes footage of the cast and crew on the set of THE KING OF KINGS. Shot for publicity use, these clips and stills show the dimension and scale of a DeMille production in full swing.

This short 1974 profile by B. D. Garga, one of India’s pioneering documentary filmmakers and a leading Indian film historian, features narration by director Satyajit Ray and on-set footage from the making of THE BIG CITY.

In this interview editors Eleanor Hamerow, professor and former chair of the graduate film program at New York University, and Miriam Arsham, a longtime collaborator of Nathan Kroll's, discuss their work on A DANCER'S WORLD, APPALACHIAN SPRING, and NIGHT JOURNEY.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Raoul Coutard on SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER
Description: Legendary cinematographer Raoul Coutard began his career collaborating with some of the most celebrated directors of the French new wave and went on to shoot more than seventy feature films. In 2003, he was interviewed in Paris and discussed SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER, his first film with director François Truffaut.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): “Télécinéma”: MY NIGHT AT MAUD’S Actor and Producer
Description: In this 1974 episode of the French television show “Télécinéma,” directed by Jacques Brialy, host Olivier Lorsac interviews film critic Jean Douchet, actor Jean-Louis Trintignant, and producer Pierre Cottrell.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Luciana Arrighi on MY BRILLIANT CAREER
Description: In this interview, recorded in Los Angeles in 2018, production designer Luciana Arrighi talks about her first collaboration with director Gillian Armstrong, on MY BRILLIANT CAREER.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Donald Richie on AU HASARD BALTHAZAR
Description: Film scholar Donald Richie talks about why he considers himself a “Bressonian” in this interview, recorded in New York in November 2004.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Francesco Rosi on HANDS OVER THE CITY
Description: Director Francesco Rosi talks about his approach to filmmaking and the production of his fourth film, HANDS OVER THE CITY, in this 2006 interview.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Tony Rayns on THE INSECT WOMAN
Description: This interview with film critic Tony Rayns was conducted in December 2008.

Directed by René Clément • 1936 • France /  /  /  / This thirteen-minute short, written by Jacques Tati and directed by René Clément, stars Tati as a farmer who dreams of becoming a boxer but is ill-prepped when he gets his wish.
The following interview with actor Michael Fassbender was conducted by film critic Jason Solomons in 2008.

In 1970, Roberto Rossellini was invited to Rice University to present his films to students and participate in videotaped discussions with faculty members. The following are excerpts from those rare archival tapes. Leading the discussion is James Blue, then director of Rice Media Center. Also present are professors Colin Young and David MacDougall.

Directed by Kevin Meul • 2010 • Belgium /  / It seems Rocky was born on the wrong side of luck; all the people he loves die from a fatal accident. First his father, then his grandfather and every single time Rocky is at the center of it all. He is like a magnet for misfortune. Rocky's mom is bitter because she loses her husband and dad. She's unable to comfort Rocky because she is not capable of dealing with her own grief. Celine's cold attitude makes Rocky believe he's the cause of all their misery. It's with these delusional ideas that he grows older. Luckily, Rocky meets Angie, the love of his life. But Angie has her own problems...

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Ang Lee on A TOUCH OF ZEN
Description: In this 2016 interview, Academy Award–winning filmmaker Ang Lee describes his appreciation for A TOUCH OF ZEN and the influence it had on his own acclaimed martial arts film CROUCHING TIGER, HIDDEN DRAGON (2000).

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): The Darkness of War in WOODEN CROSSES
Description: Professor Kristin Thompson explores how Raymond Bernard evoked the horror and despair of battle in his shatteringly realistic World War I film.

Shot in 2016 for the Criterion Collection, this new interview with Sensei Yoshimitsu Katsuse, fifteenth headmaster of the Suio-ryu martial arts system, documents and demonstrates the reality of samurai swordsmanship in contrast to its fictitious representation of the Lone Wolf and Cub film series.
Actor Candice Bergen and director Louis Malle were married for fifteen years, until his death in 1995. This interview with Bergen was recorded in 2005.
Directed by Hal Roach • 1919 • United States /  / Harold Lloyd plays a young man who attempts to avoid many obstacles in order to marry his boss's daughter.

This interview with ORPHEUS assistant director Claude Pinoteau, about the special effects in Jean Cocteau’s films, was conducted and directed by filmmaker Marc Caro (Delicatessen, City of Lost Children) in 2008.
In this 2005 interview, Henning Bendtsen talks about his early experiences as a young director of photography for Carl Theodor Dreyer and about his final films, made with Lars von Trier.

Presented here is a 2009 interview with Benedict Fitzgerald, whose screenwriting credits include the made-for-television films HEART OF DARKNESS, IN COLD BLOOD, and ZELDA, as well as the most successful independent film of all time, THE PASSION OF THE CHRIST. WISE BLOOD was his first film.

Professor Kristin Thompson breaks down the lush palette of Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger’s sensuous masterpiece, showing how set designer Alfred Junge and cinematographer Jack Cardiff use splashes of color to trace the film’s emotional arc.

Tony Aboyantz’s first job in film was as an assistant director on LE PLAISIR. He worked with Ophuls again on LOLA MONTES, then went on to be an assistant director for Jean Girault for many years. This 1989 interview was conducted in Paris by Martina Muller.
This piece, shot in April 2011, features Denis Lenoir, one of CARLOS’s two cinematographers.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Tony Rayns on AN ACTOR’S REVENGE
Description: In this interview, filmmaker, critic, and festival programmer Tony Rayns examines the themes and visual styles of AN ACTOR’S REVENGE and places the film in the context of Kon Ichikawa’s oeuvre.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Hans Hirschmüller on THE MERCHANT OF FOUR SEASONS
Description: The following interview with actor Hans Hirschmüller was conducted in Berlin in February 2015.
The following five scenes were deleted from the final version of THE PLAYER. Also presented are some outtakes from the LONELY ROOM scene, featuring actors Lily Tomlin and Scott Glenn.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Tatsuya Nakadai on WHEN A WOMAN ASCENDS THE STAIRS
Description: Tatsuya Nakadai has acted for some of Japan’s greatest directors, including Masaki Kobayashi, Akira Kurosawa, Hiroshi Teshigahara, and Mikio Naruse, and revealed an impressive range, playing everything from samurai to the bar manager Kenichi Komatsu in WHEN A WOMAN ASCENDS THE STAIRS. In this 2005 interview, Nakadai discusses his work with Naruse.
Directed by Eric Rohmer • 1964 • France /  / A university student wanders around Paris in this short film by Eric Rohmer.
This 2010 program includes interviews with HUNGER director Steve McQueen, actors Michael Fassbender, Liam Cunningham, Stuart Graham, and Brian Milligan, writer Enda Walsh, and producer Robin Gutch.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): David Simon on PATHS OF GLORY
Description: In this episode of our ongoing Under the Influence series, “The Wire” creator David Simon draws deep and surprising connections between his groundbreaking television series and Stanley Kubrick’s 1957 antiwar classic PATHS OF GLORY. Recalling his experience viewing the film with a group of Baltimore detectives, the writer and producer discusses how Kubrick’s portrayal of a callous and hypocritical military bureaucracy served as a model of narrative and political complexity for his own sprawling story of institutional dysfunction.

Directed by Charles Burnett • 1995 • United States /  /  /  / Charles Burnett paints a jazz- and poetry-inflected portrait of African American community and resilience via the story of a mother who enlists a musician’s help when she is evicted on New Year’s Day. /  /  /  / Limited engagement ends September 30
Directed by Krzysztof Kieślowski • 1980 • Poland /  /  /  / Krzysztof Kieślowski began his career making documentaries. Presented here is RAILWAY STATION, one of his nonfiction shorts.

Directed by Caroline Monnet and Daniel Watchorn • 2014 • Canada /  / An eight year old girl and her infant cousin experience a series of traumatic events while quarantined in the infirmary of a residential school for Native children in Canada.
Directed by Lucas Leyva and Jillian Mayer • 2017 • United States /  /  /  / A day in the life of a Husband and a Wife, living in a world of giant monsters.
The following selected-scene commentary, recorded for Les Films de Mon Oncle in 2013, features theater director Jérôme Deschamps.

Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1938 • France /  / Inspired by the groundbreaking use of film in the analysis of movement by physiologist Étienne-Jules Marey, Jean Painlevé animated the opéra bouffe BLUEBEARD, about the legendary knight, using clay dolls made by sculptor René Bertrand and Bertrand's three young children.

Days after Marco Ferreri’s death in May 1997, filmmakers Francesco Rosi and Bernardo Bertolucci and film historian Aldo Tassone took part in a roundtable discussion about the director for the French television show “Le cercle de minuit.” Excerpts are presented here, including interview clips with Ferreri from January of the same year.
Directed by Chantal Akerman • 1968• Belgium /  /  /  / Directed by and starring Chantal Akerman, this short film was made when she was just eighteen.

Presented here is CRONENBERG: THE EARLY YEARS, a 2011 interview with David Cronenberg, conducted by “Fangoria” editor in chief Chris Alexander, in which the director discusses his transition from the experimental filmmaking of STEREO (1969) and CRIMES OF THE FUTURE (1970) to working within the commercial Canadian film industry.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Widescreen Composition in SHOOT THE PIANO PLAYER
Description: Professor Jeff Smith explores how François Truffaut harnesses the 2.35:1 aspect ratio in his wildly playful gangster-movie pastiche, a giddy high point in the French New Wave’s assault on cinematic convention.

Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1972 • France /  /  /  / The lives of miniscule mollusks are intimately captured as they wallow in mud, mate and give birth. Director Jean Painlevé sublimely sets their dance like movements to music.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): On the Set of EMPIRE OF PASSION
Description: This program, created by Argos Films in 2003, features EMPIRE OF PASSION production consultant Koji Wakamatsu and assistant directors Yusuke Narita and Yoichi Sai.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): A WELL SPENT LIFE: No Man Like Mance
Description: This short documentary, produced in 2014, features interviews with Skip Gerson, director Les Blank’s collaborator on A WELL SPENT LIFE; Blank’s sons, Beau and Harrod; and Chris Strachwitz, founder of Arhoolie Records.

The following excerpts are from French television interviews that aired when 2 OR 3 THINGS I KNOW ABOUT HER was in production. In this excerpt from the October 25, 1966, episode of “Zoom,” produced by André Harris, Jean-Luc Godard engages in a sociopolitical debate with government official Jean St. Geours.
The following interview with STILL WALKING cinematographer Yutaka Yamazaki was shot in August 2010 at the International House of Japan in Tokyo, with Yamazaki acting as cameraman.

Author and poet David Constantine was surprised to learn that his short story “In Another Country” had been optioned to be adapted into a film. In this interview, conducted in 2016, Constantine discusses his story, the changes director Andrew Haigh made in adapting it, and how he feels about the final film.

Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1927 • France /  / From 1927 to 1928, Jean Painlevé made his first three films aimed at the general public. Shown in 'ciné-clubs' and avant-garde movie theaters of Paris, these films were written and edited to entertain as well as educate. THE OCTOPUS, one of these educational films, is presented here in its original silent version.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Isaach de Bankolé on WHITE MATERIAL
Description: This interview with actor Isaach de Bankolé was recorded in 2010.
This selected-scene commentary, recorded for Les Films de Mon Oncle in 2013, features Jacques Tati scholar Stéphane Goudet.
In this April 2012 interview, LE HAVRE star André Wilms talks about the film and working with Aki Kaurismäki, who also directed him in LA VIE DE BOHÈME.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): The Story of French Cinema By Those Who Made It

Description: Perhaps best known in America for the design of the Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art building, architect Arata Isozaki once collaborated with Hiroshi Teshigahara as art director on his film THE FACE OF ANOTHER. The following interview with Isozaki was recorded in 2006.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): The Restless Cinematography of BREAKING THE WAVES
Description: Jeff Smith unpacks Robby Müller’s handheld camera work in Lars von Trier’s wrenching fable, showing how it alternates choppy realism with calculated stylization.
Directed by Hal Roach • 1919 • United States /  / Harold Lloyd plays Billy Blazes, a man who attempts to save Peaceful Vale from the violent Crooked Charley.

Made in 2017 by Jim Cirronella, this program features ten cast and crew members discussing what it was like to portray cinema’s original flesh-eating ghouls, in interviews shot for the 2009 documentary AUTOPSY OF THE DEAD.

THE RULES OF THE GAME originally ran 94 minutes. After a negative response, Renoir cut it to 81. During World War II, the film was destroyed by bombs. In 1959, it was reconstructed, with Renoir’s approval, from surviving elements, becoming the 106-minute version we know. Chris Faulkner compares the endings of the longest and shortest versions.

In this video essay, celebrated contemporary artist Jeff Wall, known for his sumtuous large-scale photographs and his love of cinema, examines the power of Pedro Costa's images. His words are presented alongside visuals from OSSOS.
Directed by Eric Rohmer • 1966 • France /  / An examination of the lifestyles of female college students in 1966. Directed by Eric Rohmer.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Susan Cooke Kittredge on ALL AT SEA
Description: The following interview with Susan Cooke, Alistair Cooke’s daugher, was filmed in 2010.
In this Q&A footage from a 2000 screening of PICKPOCKET at the Reflet Médicis cinema in Paris, actor Marika Green and filmmakers Paul Vecchiali and Jean-Pierre Améris field questions about the film.
In the following audio interview, recorded in Berlin on July 2, 1966, director Satyajit Ray and film journalist Gideon Bachmann discuss the recurring theme of progress in Ray’s films.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Continuity Editing in THE DEVIL AND DANIEL WEBSTER
Description: Professor Jeff Smith walks us through the basics of continuity editing and shows how William Dieterle’s faustian fever dream adheres to that code while testing the limits of its expressive potential.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): The Making of ANTICHRIST: Sound and Music
Description: Made in 2010 by Zentropa’s DVD production company, Electric Parc.

Maureen Gosling, the sound recordist and assistant editor on A POEM IS A NAKED PERSON, spent two years making the film with director Les Blank, living for much of that time in northeastern Oklahoma, where Leon Russell was building a new recording studio. During that period, she shot her own Super 8 footage, a portion of which is presented here.

In 1955, producer, showman, and distributor Kroger Babb bought the American rights to SUMMER WITH MONIKA, cut it down, added a dub track and a jazz score, and distributed it as MONIKA, THE STORY OF A BAD GIRL! In this 2012 interview, film historian Eric Schaefer explains how director Ingmar Bergman’s film became grist for the exploitation mill.
Directed by Jean Painlevé • 1956 • France /  / Colorful underwater photography highlights this educational film about starfish.

“Melville on Melville,” Rui Nogueira’s 1971 book of interviews with Jean-Pierre Melville, was for decades the only English-language work devoted to the director’s films. In 2003, cinema historian Ginette Vincendeau added “Jean-Pierre Melville, An American in Paris.” In this 2005 video interview, Nogueira shares his thoughts on LE SAMOURAÏ.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): GODZILLA Cast and Crew: Akira Takarada
Description: In this 2011 interview, actor Akira Takarada recalls his experience starring as Ogata in GODZILLA.

In this 2018 video essay, filmmaker Daniel Raim explores Andrei Tarkovsky’s creative process and the unique aesthetic philosophy he applied in creating ANDREI RUBLEV, using the director’s own words from interviews and essays.

In this interview, filmed in Berlin in January 2016, cinematographer Hans Fromm describes the inspiration for the lush noir look of PHOENIX, and how his relationship with director Christian Petzold has evolved over the course of their two decades of collaboration.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Nicolas Roeg and Jeremy Thomas on INSIGNIFICANCE
Description: INSIGNIFICANCE was the third collaboration between director Nicolas Roeg and producer Jeremy Thomas. This interview with the pair was conducted in London in December 2010.
Jeff Smith walks us through Robert Altman’s most intricately allusive film, a satire that enlists genre tropes in order to send up the Hollywood assembly line that spits them out.
This interview with director Samuel Fuller was excerpted from a 1987 episode of the French television series “Cinéma cinémas.”

This interview with filmmaker Martin Scorsese was conducted in the fall of 2004. Scorsese, a fan of THE RIVER since childhood, was instrumental in the 2004 restoration of the film through his work with The Film Foundation.
Directed by Jean-Luc Godard • 1959 • France /  / A jilted man rants at his mostly silent former lover.
In this 2005 interview, conducted in Tokyo, HARAKIRI screenwriter Shinobu Hashimoto talks about his creative process in writing the script and recalls the reactions to the film.

The prolific French actor Michel Piccoli made six films with Marco Ferreri; DILLINGER IS DEAD was the first. In this interview, recorded in 2009, Piccoli discusses his experience working with Ferreri and what made the director a rarity in cinema.
In this 2014 video essay, filmmaker :: kogonada explores director Ingmar Bergman’s CRIES AND WHISPERS, a film in three movements.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Abdellatif Kechiche on THE SECRET OF THE GRAIN
Description: The following interview with director Abdellatif Kechiche was conducted in March 2010.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): B. Ruby Rich on Dorothy Arzner

Description: In this 2001 interview, Jacques Witta, editor of BLUE and RED, reveals why certain scenes (and parts of shots) in RED were ultimately removed, and shares anecdotes about director Krzysztof Kieślowski’s process in the editing room.
The following 12-minute trailer for RICHARD III was produced by Laurence Olivier and includes on-set footage of Olivier, producer Alexander Korda, and other members of the cast and crew.
The following interview with filmmaker Neil LaBute was recorded in Vancouver in 2005.
What do actors do when they act? Few aspects of film craft are as widely discussed—and as little understood.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): GIRL SHY: Harold Lloyd Meets Classical Hollywood
Description: David Bordwell shows how Harold Lloyd helped silent comedy evolve from gag-based skits to increasingly intricate narrative forms.

Acclaimed actor and director Steve Buscemi first saw SYMBIOPSYCHOTAXIPLASM TAKE ONE at the Sundance Film Festival, in 1992, and he was so taken with it and director William Greaves that he pledged his support to the film and any sequels. In this 2005 featurette, many key WATERSHIP DOWN animators and background artists recall their painstaking work on this landmark adaptation.

In this interview, conducted in August of 2005, “Cinéaste” editor Richard Porton discusses VIRIDIANA both in terms of Luis Buñuel’s style and in the context of the director’s return to his native Spain.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): Adriano Aprà on GERMANY YEAR ZERO
Description: Film historian and teacher Adriano Aprà has devoted much of his career to Roberto Rossellini and his films, directing the 1992 film ROSSELLINI VISTO DA ROSSELLINI, editing the 1992 collection of Rossellini essays and interviews “My Method,” and writing the 2006 book “In viaggio con Rossellini.” This interview with Apra, in which he discusses GERMANY YEAR ZERO, was conducted in 2009.
In this 2016 interview, Jan-Christopher Horak, director of the UCLA Film & Television Archive, discusses the importance of KAMERADSCHAFT to director G. W. Pabst’s career.

Title (Data retrieved 2019-06-21): BREAKING THE WAVES: Deleted and Extended Scenes

Description: Daniel Gelin, noted for his work with directors Jean Cocteau, Louis Malle, and Alfred Hitchcock, made two films with Max Ophuls, LA RONDE and LE PLAISIR. In this interview, conducted by Martina Muller in 1989, Gelin discusses his experiences working on LA RONDE.

In this interview by journalist Patrick Simonin, made in 2003 for the French television channel TV5 Monde, actor Nicole Stéphane reminisces about her friendship with author and filmmaker Jean Cocteau and her experiences shooting LES ENFANTS TERRIBLES.
In this 2016 piece, filmmaker and cultural theorist Manthia Diawara (“African Film: New Forms and Aesthetics and Politics”) addreses the significance of Ousmane Sembène's debut film.
